NEW DELHI: Breaking its two-session winning run, Shares of Zee Entertainment cracked 30.92 per cent to Rs 229.70 on the NSE on Friday, logging its worst-ever fall. Zee Entertainment's subsidiary Dish TV also tanked 37.41 per cent to Rs 21.

A report in Wire said that a link has emerged between Essel Group and a company being probed for suspect demonetisation deposits.

"Dreamline Manpower Solutions, a company being probed by the SFIO, carried out transactions involving a few Essel entities in 2016-17 and is also at the heart of a legal spat between Videocon and Essel," a Wire report said.


Also read: No DeMo-related SFIO probe in Zee, Dish: Jawahar Goel

Zee Entertainment clarifiesLater, Zee Entertainment in a clarification said that the company is unaware of the news item and factual correctness of the news report on Essel Group.

“The company is unaware of the news item referred in your letter or its source or factual correctness of the information contained therein,” the company said in a clarification to BSE.


Stake saleThere are also reports that Zee Entertainment’s promotors’ plan to sell stake in the company has gained fresh momentum.
The promoters of Zee Entertainment have zeroed in on three companies to sell half of their holding in the entity, an ET report suggested. 

The three companies include Sony Pictures, which owns rival broadcast business Sony Pictures Networks India (SPN), a US-based media conglomerate, and a Chinese company. 

The report further added, quoting a company spokesperson that the ZEE’s discussions pertaining to the stake sale with the prospective partners are on and the progress is extremely positive. 

Exceeding the market expectations, ZEE reported 50.26 per cent year-on-year rise in consolidated profit at Rs 562.38 crore for the third quarter against Rs 374.26 crore in the same period last year.

However, experts say there are headwinds affecting the company in short term which will keep the downside risk high.

"Regulatory changes in broadcasting, as the customer gets to choose what to watch, will impact the viewership and subscription revenue in short to medium term and will eventually impact the valuations as advertising revenue is directly related to viewership," said Sameer Kalra, founder and equity research analyst of Target Investing.

"Promoter stake sale of 25 per cent and above is another downside risk as it is a family influenced management, which reduced the incentive for minority investor," he added.

NEW DELHI: Dalal Street's relief rally didn't last long as the benchmark indices took a U-turn and ended half a per cent lower on Friday, shrugging off firmness in other markets.

Media and auto stocks took the biggest knock on a day when automaker Maruti Suzuki's poor December quarter earnings did much of the damage. 

BSE Sensex slipped 170 points to settle at 36,026 while NSE's Nifty slipped 69 points to close at 10,781. Among Sensex stocks, 10 advanced while 20 slipped. 

Maruti, HDFC Bank and ICICI Bank proved the biggest drag on the Sensex. 


Market at a glance:


>> 
Maruti threw a curveball
Maruti Suzuki reported a 17 per cent plunge in net profit at Rs 1,489 crore and missed estimates, which led to a severe beating of the stock. The scrip closed 7.40 per cent lower at Rs 6,516 and was the worst index performer. Maruti was responsible for a 68-point plunge out of the total 170-point decline in Sensex. 


>> 
YES Bank on top for Day 2
YES Bank was the best index performer in Sensex pack, rallying 14 per cent in intra-day trade after it announced on Thursday the appointment of Ravneet Gill as new MD & CEO in place of Rana Kapoor. However, the stock pared most of the gains to settle the day just 2.71 per cent higher at Rs 219 apiece. 

Other gainers among Sensex stocks included HCL Tech, Bharti Airtel, TCS, Vedanata and HDFC. 


>> 
ZEEL, Dish TV bled
Shares of Zee Entertainment and Dish TV plummeted 26 per cent and 33 per cent, respectively, after online news website TheWire.in reported that a link has emerged between Essel Group and a company being probed for suspect demonetisation deposits. There were also reports that Zee Entertainment’s promotors’ plan to sell a stake in the company has gained fresh momentum. 


>> 
CBI raids DLF offices
Shares of DLF came under pressure after CBI carried out searches at 20 locations in Delhi-NCR, including offices of the realty major, on Friday in connection with alleged irregularities in land allocation in Gurgaon in 2009. The stock ended 11.50 per cent lower.


>> 
Sectoral Watch
Barring IT, all other sectoral indices closed lower on NSE with media stocks witnessing the worst hammering. The Nifty Media index tanked over 16 per cent on a massive slide in Zee Entertainment shares. 

Auto and realty were two other worst-hit sectors on NSE. Among auto stocks, Maruti Suzuki was the worst hit while in DLF was the top drag for the realty index.



Factors that dragged market:



Maruti, bank stocks bleed
Maruti Suzuki, ICICI Bank and HDFC Bank dragged Sensex lower in Friday's session. Maruti was responsible for nearly half of the point-wise decline in Sensex. ICICI Bank slipped after CBI on Thursday booked the bank's former CEO Chanda Kochhar on charges of criminal conspiracy, cheating and abuse of official position for “dishonestly sanctioning loans to the Videocon Group”.



Rupee slips
The rupee slipped against the US dollar to hit an intraday low of Rs 71.23. The domestic unit declined some 16 paise against the greenback mainly on account of rise in crude oil prices.



Rise in crude oil prices
Oil prices edged up on Friday as turmoil in Venezuela increased the chances of tighter global supply if the United States makes good on signals that it could impose sanctions on Venezuelan exports. But fresh data on surging US fuel stocks and worries about US-China trade talks weighed on prices. Brent crude oil futures traded at $61.17 a barrel, up 8 cents, or 0.13 per cent.



Expert-take:
Vinod Nair, Head of Research, Geojit Financial Services
"Market pared the opening momentum due to intensified selling in media stocks and below expected quarter results while global market rallied. Rupee weakened and 10-year yield inched higher due to concern on rise in oil prices on account of turmoil in Venezuela. Market may extend the range bound movement as global risk factors like US China trade talks and growth concern continued to gain investor’s attention."


Rajah Yadav, Sr. Research Analyst, 
Today trading session remained very much volatile as after making a gap up opening, market ended with half a percent of cut. It continued to trade in the green in the afternoon session driven by some stock specific movements. However, in the late afternoon session, heavy selling was witnessed in auto, media and banking stocks that weighed down the market. Index heavyweight like Maruti Suzuki and Ultratech were down over 7 per cent after posting weaker than expected results. Zee Entertainment was down ~30 per cent amid some business concern. Broader indices continued to face sharp selling and both mid and small cap indices were down over 1.3 per cent. Stock-specific movement in the ongoing earning season continues to dominate the market trend in coming sessions.

NEW DELHI: Disappointing December quarter earnings of Maruti Suzuki, the country’s largest carmaker, weighed in on market sentiment, causing the benchmark indices to settle in the negative territory on Friday.

The market traded steady all through the first half of the session, but took a plunge after Maruti came out with a set of numbers that fell below expectations. 

A wave of selling emerged across sectors, led by auto, media, realty and bank stocks, which erased all the gains of the morning session and made Sensex and Nifty close in the red. 

Positive mood of most emerging markets failed to lift the mood. A 170 points, or 0.47 per cent, fall dragged Sensex to 36,025 at close. Nifty lost 69 points, or 0.64 per cent, to settle at 10,780.

Midcaps and smallcaps suffered most as their sectoral indices plunged up to 1.58 per cent.


Let us walk you through the highlights of the day’s proceedings:

Maruti's misery continuesThe automaker maintained negative trend in quarterly earnings. A 17.21 per cent drop in third quarter profit marked the second consecutive quarter of negative growth. On the back of a 10 per cent YoY slippage in September quarter profit, December quarter numbers turned out to be worse; and worst ever since March quarter of 2014. Maruti reported 35.46 per cent quarterly de-growth in profit after tax. The scrip closed 8.11 per cent down at Rs 6,469 on NSE.


Zee logs worst-ever fallShares of Zee Entertainment tanked 30.92 per cent to Rs 229 on NSE, logging their worst-ever fall. Company's subsidiary Dish TV tanked 37.41 per cent to Rs 21. Both stocks crumbled after reports that a link has emerged between Essel Group and a company being probed for suspect deposits during the demonetisation drive. “Dreamline Manpower Solutions, a company being probed by the SFIO, carried out transactions involving a few Essel entities in 2016-17 and is also at the heart of a legal spat between Videocon and Essel," the report said. However, Zee told BSE it was not aware of any such probe.


Indian Bank plunges as Q3 profit halvesIndian Bank's third quarter profit halved to Rs 152.26 crore on account of rising provisions for bad loans. The bank had posted a net profit of Rs 303.06 crore in the corresponding October-December period of the previous financial year. The stock closed 7.23 per cent down at Rs 237.45 on NSE. 


Pfizer rises on Q3 numbersShares of Pfizer jumped 3.53 per cent to Rs 2,777, a day after it reported a 51.24 per cent rise in profit at Rs 131.94 crore for the quarter ended December 2018 against Rs 87.24 crore reported for the previous quarter ended December 2017. 


YES Bank extends gainsShares of YES Bank closed 2.11 per cent higher at Rs 219, extending the gains into the third consecutive session. The company has named Ravneet Singh Gill as the new MD and CEO to succeed Rana Kapoor, whose term ends on January 31. After a subdued set of December quarter numbers, global brokerage firm CLSA has maintained a ‘Buy’ call on the stock with a target price of Rs 280. It added that clarity on new strategy and management churn is to be watched. 


DLF plunges 10% after CBI raidsShares of realty major DLF cracked 10.27 per cent to Rs 159.50 after CBI carried out searches at 20 locations in Delhi-NCR, including its offices, in connection with alleged irregularities in land allocation in Gurgaon in 2009. A PTI report said CBI has registered a new case against former Haryana chief minister Bhupinder Singh Hooda over glaring irregularities in acquisition of 1,417 acres land by the then Haryana government in Gurgaon in 2009. 


L&T falls 1% ahead of Q3 numbersShares of Engineering conglomerate Larsen & Toubro closed 0.56 per cent down at Rs 1,288 on Friday ahead of its third-quarter numbers. Post market hours, the company posted a 37.02 per cent year-on-year (YoY) jump in Q3 profit at Rs 2,041 crore over Rs 1,489.98 crore in Q3FY18. The numbers came as better-than-expected as analysts in an ET Now poll had estimated a profit of Rs 1,860 crore. 


110 stocks signal potential fallAdani Power, Punj Lloyd, JSW Steel, Zee Media Corp, United Breweries and Greaves Cotton were among 110 stocks that showed bearish crossovers on BSE, as per the momentum indicator moving average convergence divergence, or MACD. Meanwhile, 35 stocks, including Vedanta, InterGlobe Aviation, BPCL, Kaveri Seed Company, Oberoi Realty and Pfizer, showed bullish crossovers on BSE.


Nifty Media top sectoral loserThe media index suffered a 16.37 per cent loss, owing to deep cuts in shares of Dish TV India, Zee Entertainment and Zee Media Corporation. Out of 15 components on the index, 11 closed the day with losses, 3 logged gains and 1 remained unchanged.


IT pack lone sectoral gainerThe IT index closed as the lone sectoral gainer on NSE. The index closed with a nominal gain of 0.45 per cent, backed by rise in shares of HCL Tech (up 3.02 per cent), TCS (up 0.94 per cent), Wipro (up 0.70 per cent) and Tech Mahindra (up 0.45 per cent).

NEW DELHI: After Zee group stocks took a heavy beating on Friday, Subhash Chandra, Chairman of ZEE and Essel Group in an open letter said that certain “negative forces” attacked the stock of Zee Entertainment to sabotage the company’s strategic sale process.

In the letter, Chandra said that buying D2H from Videocon was a wrong investment decision and he made some incorrect bids in the infra space. 

Shares of Zee Entertainment cracked 30.92 per cent to Rs 229.70 on the NSE on Friday, logging its worst-ever fall after a report in the Wire said that a link had emerged between Essel Group and a company being probed for suspect demonetisation deposits. 

"Dreamline Manpower Solutions, a company being probed by the SFIO, carried out transactions involving a few Essel entities in 2016-17 and is also at the heart of a legal spat between Videocon and Essel," a Wire report said.

Zee Entertainment’s subsidiary Dish TV also tanked 37.41 per cent to Rs 21. 

In the letter Chandra also urged the lenders not to react in an anarchical manner and to maintain patience, till the process of ZEE Entertainment’s stake sale was completed.


Here’s the full text of the letter:At a very early stage of my life, I have learnt the most important lesson from my grandfather, Shri Jagannath Goenka, which taught me that a direct dialogue with the creditors should be maintained, should you find it difficult to repay any sort of loans, and this message is my earnest effort in doing so.

First and foremost, vide this message I would like to express my deepest apologies to our esteemed financial supporters. I have always been the first to accept my faults and we have been consistently accountable of the decisions taken, and I will maintain the same today as well. For the first time in my career of 52 years, I am compelled to apologize to our bankers, NBFCs & Mutual Funds, since I believe that I have not lived upto to their expectations, despite the best of my intentions.

I am extremely certain that there is no promoter in India Inc., who has dared to sell the jewel of his crown, to pay off the liabilities. While the process is still ongoing, there are some forces which are not willing to see us succeed.

That said, I am not indicating that there are no mistakes done from my end, and as always, I am willing to face the consequences of the same. I assure you, that I am not running away from the core issue and will do my best to repay each and every person. The best time for the same, however, is difficult to be mentioned at this stage.


I would also like to state through this message, the key points which have gone wrong:



Essel Infra: As most of the infra companies, even we have made some incorrect bids. In usual cases, Infra Companies have raised their hands and have left their lenders with nonperforming assets, but in our case, My Obsession of not walking away from the situation, has made me to bleed Rs 4,000 crore to Rs 5,000 crore . Despite the loss making projects, we continued to pay the interest and the principle, by borrowing funds against ourshareholdings in Listed Companies.
Acquisition of D2H: My recommendation made to my brother Jawahar Goel to buy D2H from Videocon was one more key error, which costed me and Jawahar both, a fortune.
When our family business separation was implemented, as the eldest member of the family, I had taken the entire burden of the debts. I believe, it was my mistake to have told myself that “Subhash you can earn and repay the creditors”. Post which, most of my bets on the new businesses have not worked, which led to the increased debt, due to the added interest levels.
The situation at hand, became further unmanageable after the IL&FS issue, came to public light. Till then, we were managing our borrowings efficiently. The IL&FS meltdown stopped the roll overs, diminishing our ability to service our borrowings.
From May / June 2018 onwards a negative force which was acting against our grip as promoters became strongly active. This was followed by some anonymous letters being sent to all Bankers, NBFCs, Mutual Funds, Shareholders, etc.
Whenever we have reported some really good results from the operating Companies, the share prices were intentionally hammered by these negative forces, driving away the investors.


While the above, are the reasons of the current situation, I must also mention what steps were taken from our end:


We wrote a number of complaints to the Department of Police, Home Minister of Maharashtra, SEBI and other concerned authorities, right since November 2018, but all the efforts did not result in any action.
Till December, we continued to pay the due interest and principle, to all lenders.
I have also given my best to expedite the stake sale of ZEE Entertainment. Infact, I have just returned back from London, last night itself, after a series of positive meetings with potential suitors.

The mentioned negative forces, possibly after getting a hint of these positive meetings, have attacked the share price today, with a clear intention of sabotaging ZEE Entertainment’s strategic sale process.

I must also mention that there is no systematic protection against the insidious attack on us by the mentioned negative forces, but we will continue to seek the support of the system in order to thoroughly investigate the matter.


About the Operating Companies:


All Operating Companies, especially our most precious one which is ZEE Entertainment, are performing exceptionally well and are under NO stress whatsoever. The debt burden is purely at the promoter level, which is reflecting negatively on the Companies.
I would like to reiterate that ALL the Companies are performing exceptionally well and there is no problem whatsoever.

Having said the above, I still believe, strongly feel and would like to urge the lenders, not to react in an anarchical manner and to maintain patience, till the process of ZEE Entertainment’s stake sale is completed. Post the sale process, we will be positively able to repay the entire dues, but if the lenders react in a panic situation, it will only hurt them and us.

I would again like to reiterate that I have no intention whatsoever, to keep a single rupee, till all the dues to the lenders are paid.

Yours truly,

Subhash Chandra

Jawahar Goel, CMD, Dish TV, says their team had arranged loan to Videocon Group in lieu of the pledge of their 
  
  
  D2H shares and this money had come from the banks and it was not a cash but a bank-to-bank transaction and had nothing to do with demonetisation. Goel also says 20 of their distributors had put Rs 7 crore money in their bank account after demonetisation but they had already replied to I-T department about it.Edited excerpts:

We are seeing a massive market cap meltdown in Zee Entertainment and Dish TV. Is there any concerns with respect to any probes that are currently being conducted with respect to demonetisation with the Essel Group? Can you please clarify?
Dish TV Essel Group has got nothing to do with it. In Dish TV our daily collection is around Rs 20 crore and Dish TV had only Rs 22,000 cash in hand at the time of demonetisation. However, some 20 of our distributors had put money in our bank account to the tune of Rs 7 crore. They are PAN holders. About all these things, we had adequately replied to the income tax department.


There is a lot of nervousness on the Street today. With respect to Dish TV right now, is it business as usual? Are any probes being conducted?
No there is no probe in Dish TV or on the Zee side or in Essel Group. But definitely, because of the pledge issue, there is a pressure and as our group has decided to partly sell Zee TV, quite a lot of people have shown interest. Two are very serious contenders. That transaction will take three to six months. On business side, you must have seen the excellent results of Zee as well as Dish TV. 

Businesses are very good and are pretty well intact. The new tariff order is happening, Dish TV will get the higher EBITDA because the NCF will straightaway come to our profit. Our content cost will come down probably from 38% to 30% and that is a good thing.

Dish TV is ready to roll out the shifting of the subscribers to the new regime from 27th January midnight. And within 7th February we will shift all the subscribers.


 Since we have you with us, maybe you could just run us through the sequence of events that happened between 2015 and 2017. The report states that the Serious Fraud and Investigation Office is currently probing a company called Nityank Infrapower, formally Dreamline Manpower for deposits over Rs 3,000 crore made just after demonetisation. Examination of the document shows that Nityank and a group of shell companies carried out financial transactions that involved a few firms associated with the Essel Group between this period.
These companies are not Essel Group companies. The Videocon transaction had happened. So our team arranged the loan to Videocon Group Companies in lieu of the pledge of their shares of D2H and this money had come from the banks. It has nothing to do with demonetisation because demonetisation inquiry only happens if there is a cash deposit. If it is a banking transaction from end to end, there cannot be any such inquiry. 


What was the size of the loan and what is the status on that loan right now?
I am not directly involved in this transaction but this much I know this was a bank loan and the pledge of shares that is of D2H company. It was a bank to bank transactions.


Who did the transaction, which bank was involved in this?
You should ask the concerned officer in SFIO in Hyderabad. They will let you know and the inquiry is almost complete now.


Nityank Infrapower, formally Dreamline Manpower, is it a part of a firm that was involved with Essel Group of Subhash Chandra between 2015 and 2017?
Now they were known people. One of our managers arranged this transaction and the bank loan was raised to pay the advance in lieu of those shares that is it and this transaction has been very well explained and they are about to close the inquiry.


Do you have any idea when the SFIO will come out with a final verdict on this enquiry? It seems that there is still a lot of investigation required in the matter?
No. When there is no illegality, no cash money or public money is involved, then SFIO has nothing to do with it. They simply have to close the enquiry.


Would you be able to give us more details on that?
Well I am not in my office today so I cannot but certainly on Monday I can provide the information.


You are speaking on behalf of the entire group and saying that as of now, there is no cash money or public money involved and that SFIO will have to close that probe. Are you speaking on behalf of the company?
There is no cash money involved. Yes, yes, I know for that because our people were also called and that is why we know there is no cash money involved, there is no public money involved.


When was this probe conducted?
They started the probe seven-eight months ago.


You are saying that the probe has reached its conclusion and that the Essel Group...
No, Zee has nothing to do with it and the company is not Essel Group company.


But has that been officially communicated by SFIO? Have they given a clean chit to Zee and Dish TV?
You see they have not given clean chit but we had adequately replied to them and they know and we also know for sure that there is no cash money involved. It is banking money and it is not public money.


What about this new tariff order by TRAI is that going to impact Dish?
TRAI order will impact us positively, our EBITDA will go up, our content cost will come down and if we are successful we will garner more subscribers more than what we could have done in normal course. 


What is the outlook on your market share as well as the kind of customer addition that you could potentially see going forward?
A few weeks back, we said that we are changing our business model of getting the loss in our books. Instead, we will sell the loss and business is going as usual. The whole team is preparing for the new regime which will give us a breather on the content cost. The content cost of our immediate peers, that is cable companies, is much lower than us. Now, we will get the parity and you will see how advantageous it is for DTH companies.

MUMBAI: Zee and Essel group chairman Subhash Chandra on Friday evening issued a dramatic and unusual statement claiming that “negative forces” were trying to sabotage Zee Entertainment’s strategic sale, while acknowledging that he had committed mistakes. He apologised to his bankers, non-banking finance companies and mutual funds, after shares of group companies crashed during the day.

The immediate trigger for the sharp drop in shares (Zee Enterprises fell over 26%, Dish TV by nearly 33% and Essel Propack 16%) appeared to be a news report on the website thewire.in, which mentioned alleged links between the group and Nityank Infrapower and Multiventures, a company that is under the scrutiny of the Serious Fraud Investigation Office (SFIO) for deposits of over Rs 3,000 crore during or after demonetisation.

Some of the developments mentioned on the website had also been reported by ET on December 18.

In statements issued on Friday, Essel Propack and Zee said Nityank did not belong to Essel Group.




Chandra’s ‘open letter’ did not mention the Nityank issue. Instead, he said he was compelled to apologise to bankers, NBFCs and mutual funds as he had not lived up to their expectations.

He said wrong bets in the infrastructure sector combined with the meltdown of IL&FS had resulted in “Rs 4,000 crore to Rs 5,000 crore” of losses. The wrong infrastructure bets had left the company with nonperforming assets, he admitted.

“Despite the loss-making projects, we continued to pay the interest and the principle, by borrowing funds against our shareholdings in listed companies,” Chandra wrote in the note.

His efforts to repay creditors, Chandra said, was on account of his “obsession” with not walking away from difficult situations.

The Essel Group promoter said the company’s inability to handle debt worsened after the IL&FS meltdown. “The IL&FS meltdown stopped the rollovers, diminishing our ability to service our borrowings,” he said.


D2H Acquisition Cost a Fortune: Chandra
Chandra admitted that the ballooning debt was also a result of some other decisions, notably the acquisition of DTH operator Videocon D2H. He termed the acquisition a key error that cost him and his brother Jawahar Goel a “fortune”.

In an investor call with analysts on Friday evening, Zee MD Punit Goenka said Essel Group promoters had total debt of Rs 11,000-12,000 crore.

Chandra had pledged shares of his listed companies to borrow funds to invest in Essel Infra, the unlisted infrastructure company.

He pointed out in his mea culpa that till December, the company had paid due interest and principle to all lenders.

Hinting at possible sabotage, Chandra claimed there were was “a negative force”, which was acting against the company’s interests. He said anonymous letters were written to regulators whenever the company announced good results.

Referring to the stake sale in Zee Entertainment, Chandra said he has had good meetings with potential investors but that the “negative force” was “hammering” the stock. “The mentioned negative forces, possibly after getting a hint of these positive meetings, have attacked the share price today (Friday), with a clear intention of sabotaging Zee Entertainment’s strategic sale process,” he said.

ET reported on Friday that Chandra had held meetings in the US and London last week and that the company is now in talks with a number of players.

Chandra asked investors to repose faith in the company.


INVESTORS LOSE Rs 13,686 CRORE
The crash in the shares of group companies wiped off nearly Rs 13,686 crore of investor wealth, as per ET’s estimates.

Chandra also said that at the time of the division of his family’s business, he had taken the entire debt burden upon himself, which added to his troubles.

ET had first reported on December 18 that Nityank Infrapower and Multiventures (formerly known as Dreamline Manpower Solutions), a company with apparent links to Essel, was being investigated by the SFIO.

In a late Friday evening statement, a Zee spokesperson said: “Nityank Infrapower and Multiventures is an independent company and does not belong to Essel Group. The group at this stage does not wish to comment on the legal matter between Dish TV and Videocon Group, since the same is sub judice. As per our limited knowledge, the queries received from SFIO were directed to Nityank, regarding demonetisation.”

The statement added that the transactions referred to in media reports, “regarding involvement of Essel Group companies”, had been “undertaken with due approvals and compliance of applicable laws and regulations and through proper banking channels. The said investigation or the mentioned transactions do not have any bearing or connection with any of the operating entities of Essel Group.”

Videocon Group companies have alleged in court filings that Nityank had transferred Rs 1,626 crore to the former’s promoters by subscribing to debentures of Hindustan Oil Ventures (HOV) — a Videocon Group company.

Domebell Electronics, a Videocon Group company, approached the Delhi High Court on August 31 last year, claiming it had received payment from Essel through Nityank as an advance for selling shares in Videocon D2H, which was merged with Zee Group’s Dish TV in March last year.

Documents accessed by ET show that Nityank had also provided security in the form of HOV debentures to Yes Bank for loans worth Rs 1,600 crore taken by three Essel Group companies — RPW Projects, Pan India Network Infravest and Mumbai WTR.

Videocon first approached the Delhi High Court on the grounds that Essel had unlawfully invoked a pledge on Videocon D2H shares that were kept in its custody till the merger with Dish TV received regulatory approval.

It also claimed the shares were given as security if the merger failed, since it had already received an advance from Essel.

NEW DELHI: The Essel Group claims to have reached an understanding with lenders who hold pledged shares of the group’s promoters. This could arrest the decline in the Essel Group stocks. Group companies shares had plummeted 10-33% on Friday, triggered by reports of payment defaults and sale of pledged shares.

While the sharp fall in stock prices dented the NAVs of equity funds holding these scrips, there were fears that the crisis would spread to debt funds as well. More than Rs 8,000 crore worth of bonds and debentures issued by group companies are held by 150 debt mutual funds. Of this, Rs 6,329 is invested in 60 open-ended debt funds while the balance Rs 1,672 crore is in 90 fixed maturity plans (FMPs).

In a statement issued after the meeting with lenders, the Essel Group stated that it has been agreed that the no default will be declared due to the steep fall in price and there will be synergy and co-operation amongst lenders. A. Balasubramanian, CEO, Aditya Birla Sun Life AMC said, “We have always believed in the intrinsic value of Zee Entertainment. I am very glad with the outcome of the meeting, which enabled us to arrive at a consensus, in the interest of all stakeholders.”

The Aditya Birla Sun Life Mutual Fund is the biggest investor, with an exposure of Rs 2,936 crore spread across 28 schemes. This is almost 37% of the total debt fund exposure to the Zee group.

However, Balasubramanian is confident that the prices of these bonds and debentures will not be impacted. “These bonds are secure,” he says. 

One scheme alone has Rs 1,288 crore invested in Zee group bonds. As on 31 December 2018, the Aditya Birla Sun Life Medium Term Plan held zero-coupon bonds worth Rs 720 crore issued by Sprit Infrapower & Multiventures Pvt Ltd. (credit rating A) and Rs 568 issued by Adilink Infra & Multitrading Private Ltd (unrated). The two holdings account for 12.5% of the fund’s total Rs 10,272 crore portfolio and are its top holdings.

Another scheme, the Aditya Birla Sun Life Credit Risk Fund, held Rs 740 crore worth of zero-coupon bonds of Sprit Infrapower & Multiventures Pvt Ltd. and Adilink Infra & Multitrading Private Ltd. The two holdings account for 9.2% of its portfolio, with Sprit Infrapower as its top holding (5.62%). The Aditya Birla Sun Life Dynamic Bond Fund has over 8% of its Rs 5,136 crore portfolio invested in Sprit Infrapower bonds.

In percentage terms, Baroda Mutual Fund schemes have the largest exposure to bonds issued by Zee group companies. As on 31 December 2018, the Baroda Credit Risk Fund had Rs 168 crore invested in zero-coupon bonds of ARM Infra & Utilities Pvt Ltd. and Cyquator Media Services Pvt. Ltd. Together, this is 17.7% of its Rs 947 crore portfolio.

The silver lining for debt fund investors is the new rule that allows side pocketing of distressed assets. It is an accounting method that separates illiquid bonds from quality investments in a debt portfolio. If the Zee group bonds crash, open-ended debt funds may cushion themselves by putting them aside in a separate side portfolio. The fund’s NAV then reflect the value of the liquid assets, with a separate NAV assigned to the side pocket assets based on their estimated value.

However, this will not apply to fixed maturity plans (FMPs) where the scheme has a limited tenure and bonds are held till maturity. HDFC Mutual Fund, the second largest investor in Zee group debt with an exposure of Rs 1,196 crore, has most of its exposure through FMPs. It has invested over Rs 900 crore in bonds and debentures through 38 FMPs. Some FMPS have over 20% of their assets invested in Zee group companies.

Subhash Chandra-promoted two Essel group companies Zee Entertainment Enterprise and Dish TV on Sunday denied links with Nityank lnfrapower and Multiventures Ltd, a company being probed by the SFIO for suspicious demonetisation deposits, as claimed in a media report.

Zee Entertainment Enterprise Ltd (ZEEL), in a regulatory filing, said Nityank lnfrapower and Multiventures Ltd is an "independent company and does not belong to Essel Group".

It further said that involvement of Essel Group entities in the the Serious Fraud Investigation Office (SFIO) investigation against Nityank is being done only with "malicious intent" and "legal action as advised" is being initiated in this regard.

"At the outset, we wish to reiterate and confirm that Zee Entertainment Enterprises Ltd has no connection whatsoever with any alleged transaction(s) contained in the article published by a website," said ZEEL.

Over allegations of involvement of other Essel Group entities in the media report, the filing said that all "queries relating to demonetisation, if any, from SFIO were directed to Nityank".

The Essel group entities have already provided other information sought by the SFIO and no further information is sought from them.

"In view of above, since all information sought by SFIO has been provided by Essel Group entities and no further information has been subsequently sought, the matter stands closed for Essel Group entities," said ZEEL.

While its DTH arm Dish TV has also denied any transaction with Nityank in its scheme of merger of Videocon D2h with the company.

"In response to communication received by the Company in July 2018 from SFIO, seeking information relating to Nityank Infra power and Multiventures Ltd (Nityank), while providing requisite information/replies including relating to Scheme of Arrangement for Amalgamation of Videocon D2h Limited with and into Dish TV India Ltd, the company had categorically denied having had any transaction with Nityank," it said.

On January 25, shares of ZEE group companies had come under massive selling pressure, plummeting up to 33 per cent, and suffered a combined erosion of Rs 13,352 crore in market valuation.

Later, Essel Group chairman Subhash Chandra apologised to lenders and said his company is in a financial mess and blamed the same for the aggressive bets on infra, which has gone out of control since the IL&FS crisis and also the acquisition of Videocon's D2H business.

Chandra also alleged that some negative forces are out to sabotage his efforts to raise money through a strategic sale in the flagship company Zee Entertainment Enterprises.

The Essel Group management on Sunday claimed it had reached an understanding with lenders and mutual funds, with which the promoters have pledged shares against advances.

“In view of the sensitive situation triggered due to the steep fall of the stock price of ZEE Entertainment Enterprises and Dish TV, a detailed meeting of the Essel Group Promoters with the lending entities comprising of Mutual Funds, NBFCs and Banks was conducted, the company said in a press release.

Domestic mutual funds have large exposure to the two companies. More than Rs 8,000 crore worth of bonds and debentures issued by group companies are held by 150 debt funds.

The Aditya Birla Sun Life Mutual Fund is the biggest investor, with an exposure of Rs 2,936 crore spread across 28 schemes. This is almost 37% of the total debt fund exposure to the Zee group.


Also Read:
Debt funds have over Rs 8,000 crore invested in Zee group firms

Essel Group said in a meeting held on Sunday, the lenders asserted their belief in the intrinsic value of ZEE Entertainment and Dish TV, resulting into the following decisions:


There will not be any event of default declared due to the steep fall in price.
As a result of the above, there will be synergy and co-operation, amongst lenders leading to a unified approach.
Lenders drew comfort from reiteration by the promoters for a speedy resolution through a strategic sale in a time bound manner.
“I am pleased to share that we have achieved an understanding with lenders. We have always valued their immense trust and faith sown in us and the positive and progressive outcome of the meeting, is a true example of the same. I am very positive, that we will continue to take such positive steps in rising up from the current challenging times, with support of all stakeholders,” Essel Group chairman Subhash Chandra said in the statement.

A Balasubramanian, CEO, Aditya Birla Sun Life AMC, said: “We have always believed in the intrinsic value of ZEE Entertainment and most above, the sheer value system with which its promoters function. I am very glad with the outcome of the meeting, which enabled us to arrive at a consensus, in the interest of all stakeholders.”

Promoter and chairman of the Essel Group Subhash Chandra got a threemonth breather from lenders and creditors to find a buyer for half his stake in the flagship Zee Entertainment Enterprises (ZEE) in a major relief for the Indian entertainment giant.

ZEE promoters and their lenders also agreed that the latter will ensure no default is declared due to the steep fall in share price of the company.

Chandra on Friday issued an unusually dramatic statement claiming “negative forces” were trying to sabotage his efforts to find a buyer. He simultaneoulsy apologised to investors for his strategic mistakes. On Saturday, he had hectic parleys with mutual funds, NBFCs and banks, which went way past midnight.

“Lenders have given Chandra three months to find a buyer. They have agreed that the fundamentals of ZEE are strong and there is no current need to panic, and they seem to have agreed to not invoke the pledged shares,” a highly placed source said.

ZEE said on Sunday it was decided there will be synergy and cooperation amongst lenders for a unified approach.

“I am pleased to share that we have achieved an understanding with lenders,” Chandra said. “We have always valued their immense trust and faith sown in us and the positive and progressive outcome of the meeting is a true example of the same. I am very positive that we will continue to take such positive steps in rising up from the current challenging times with support of all stakeholders.”

“We have always believed in the intrinsic value of Zee Entertainment and most of all the sheer value system with which its promoters function. I am very glad with the outcome of the meeting, which enabled us to arrive at a consensus in the interest of all stakeholders,” said A Balasubramanian, CEO, Aditya Birla Sun Life AMC.

Aditya Birla Sun Life Mutual Fund, HDFC, Franklin Templeton, ICICI Prudential, Baroda Mutual Fund are among top investors with biggest exposure in Zee group companies.

As of December 31, 2018, ZEE promoters owned 41.62 per cent in the company of which 59.37 per cent are pledged with lenders.

Sources said that on Friday, when ZEE shares started nosediving, about 62-63 lakh pledged shares, or 0.65 per cent of company’s total share capital and just under 1.5 per cent of promoters’ shareholding, were sold.

“After Saturday’s meetings, ZEE promoters have managed to buy some time. Though there is nothing wrong with ZEE, a lot will depend on how soon they manage to get a buyer and how long they can stop lenders from invoking the pledged shares,” said an analyst who did not wish to be identified.

ZEE’s shares crashed 26 per cent, while other Essel group companies — Dish TV and Essel Propack — plummeted 32 per cent and 12 per cent, respectively, on Friday, the biggestever single-day crash for the companies. As per ET estimates, the crash eroded nearly Rs 13,686 crore in investor wealth.

Rajiv Sharma of SBICAP Securities, in his report on January 21st, maintained a buy for ZEE shares with a target price of Rs 550. “We believe investor concerns around the future prospects of TV are overdone and the market is not pricing in Zee’s ability to create value in OTT after inducting a strategic partner. We are valuing the core business at Rs 520 and the OTT business at Rs 30 per share,” the report said.

On November 13, 2018, Cahndra announced his intention to sell half of promoters’ holding in ZEE to a global strategic investor as it wants to transfer business into content technology company in view of the changing landscape of the Indian media with data growth. However, there were also concerns on high promoter pledge and liquidity issues in group’s various Infra businesses.


ZEE SAID ESSEL DOES NOT OWN NITYANK
The shares of ZEE group companies tanked after reports about alleged links between the group and Nityank Infrapower and Multiventures, a company under the scrutiny of investigative authorities for deposits of over Rs 3000 crore during or after the November 2016 demonetisation.

However, Essel Group and ZEE have denied ownership of Nityank.

ZEE said on Sunday that Essel Group filed a “legal case against the media platform, which has maliciously attempted to establish a linkage between the SFIO’s investigation and ZEE promoters.”

ZEE also said that all queries relating to demonetisation from SFIO were directed to Nityank and all the information/ documents relating to certain transactions sought by SFIO were provided.

“As the letter reads, since all information sought by SFIO has been provided by Essel Group entities and no further information has been subsequently sought, the matter stands closed for Essel Group entities,” ZEE informed bourses on Sunday.

NEW DELHI: Shares of Zee Entertainment jumped nearly 15 per cent in Monday’s trade after the company said it has reached a deal with lenders on pledged shares.

The scrip closed 15.45 per cent up at Rs 368.70 on BSE.

The company said 96-97 per cent of the lenders have agreed not to revoke shares were the shares to fall further. After the agreement, the company has not pledged further shares as collateral after Friday’s sharp fall, said CEO Punit Goenka said in an investor call.

There is standstill on part of lenders for now, Goenka said. The management said that stake sale in Zee will not be hit by recent developments.

Following the revocation of shares by on Friday, promoter holding has dropped 60 basis points to 41 per cent.

The lenders have given the company enough time that exceeds the April deadline the company has sought to get a strategic partner in. “It’s a collective deal that covers all aspects,” Goenka said in a conference call.

Lenders drew comfort from reiteration by the promoters for a speedy resolution through a strategic sale in a time bound manner, the company had told stock exchanges on Sunday.

Meanwhile, media reports suggested Reliance Jio has shown interest in buying half of promoter Subhash Chandra’s stake in Zee Entertainment Enterprises. 

With this, the Mukesh Ambani-led entity has joined the race with global players such as Amazon, Apple, Tencent, Alibaba, AT&T, Singtel, Comcast and Sony Pictures. 

Earlier in November 2018, Subhash Chandra had said he was planning to sell 50 per cent of his stake in Zee in a bid to secure large-scale financial backing and compete in a market prone to major technological disruptions.

NEW DELHI: A jump in Asian equities tracking Friday’s Wall Street gains is a positive signal for the Indian market, but all eyes will be Q3 earnings and on how Essel group stocks perform following Friday's crash.Let's check out what all might matter to Dalal Street on Monday:


Singapore trading sets stage for a positive start
Nifty futures on the Singapore Exchange were trading 18 points, or 0.17 per cent, higher at 10,812.50, indicating a positive start for the Nifty50.


OthersSource: sgxnifty.org

Nifty forms bearish candle
Nagaraj Shetti of HDFC Securities believes the key resistance level of 10,850 is proving too big a hurdle for Nifty50 to take out. The near-term trend looks weak and the 10,700-680 range will be the next downside support to watch out for, he said. If the index holds below 10,850, it can slip towards 10,700 and then 10,650 levels,” said Chandan Taparia of Motilal Oswal Securities. 


Asian shares up tracking Wall Street gains
Asian stocks advanced on Monday as Wall Street rallied after a deal was announced to reopen the US government following a prolonged shutdown that had shaken investor sentiment, Reuters reported. MSCI’s broadest index of Asia-Pacific shares outside Japan climbed 0.2 per cent. South Korea's KOSPI edged up 0.2 per cent, New Zealand stocks were up a touch, while Japan's Nikkei bucked the trends and eased 0.2 per cent


Oil prices drop on likely rise in production
Oil prices fell on Monday after US energy firms added rigs for the first time this year in a sign that crude production there will rise further, Reuters reported. International Brent crude oil futures were at $61.37 a barrel, down 27 cents, or 0.4 per cent.


BoJ minutes show disagreement over bond yield Bank of Japan policymakers disagreed over the appropriate level of bond yields, minutes from the central bank’s meeting last month showed in a sign of the strain on the BOJ’s monetary framework as the global economy weakens, Reuters reported.


Dollar drops ahead of Fed meet
The dollar was down on Monday, not far off more than one-week lows as financial markets shifted their attention to this week’s Federal Reserve rates-setting review with traders wagering policymakers would signal a pause to their tightening cycle. The Federal Open Market Committee meets between Jan 29-30.


US stocks jump on shutdown deal
The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 183.96 points, or 0.75 per cent, to 24,737.2, the S&P500 index gained 22.43 points, or 0.85 per cent, to 2,664.76 and the Nasdaq Composite index added 91.40 points, or 1.29 per cent, to 7,164.86, Reuters reported.


Tata Power, BoI to report Q3 results
Bank of India, Canara Bank, CEAT, Escorts, Godrej Industries, RBL Bank, Tata Power, Piramal Enterprises, Persistent Systems, Praj Industries and TTK Prestige will be among companies, which will announce their December quarter results on Monday.


All eyes on Zee, Dish TV stocks
The prospect of a further plunge in the shares of Zee Entertainment and Dish TV, which would deepen the disarray in the Essel Group, has put their managements and investors on edge. Following the sharp selloff on Friday, mutual funds holding debt securities of entities owned by Essel Group’s promoters led by Subhash Chandra face the risk of investments being marked down, leading to an erosion in the value of schemes and sparking a crisis of confidence in the debt market.


Chalet Hotels IPO to open on Tuesday
Chalet Hotels, owner, developer and asset manager of high-end hotels has proposed to open its initial public offering (IPO) on January 29, 2019. The IPO consists of equity shares of face value of Rs 10 each aggregating up to Rs 9,500 million (fresh issue) and an offer for sale of upto 24,685,000 equity shares (offered shares). 


RBI may release bank NPA data 
The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) is weighing a plan to release data that would demonstrate that the number of corporates defaulting on bank loans have dipped following the central bank’s stern directive on February 12 last year that had rattled large, influential borrowers and irked many within the government.


CCD founder to free up attached Mindtree shares
Café Coffee Day founder VG Siddhartha will offer alternative security to the income tax department to free up shares in Mindtree that have been attached, stalling attempts to sell his stake in the software company, said people with knowledge of the matter. This could include shares of other companies, bank guarantees or a bond, said the people cited above. It is not clear whether the shares of Coffee Day Enterprises will be offered.


CBI had almost closed PE against Kochhars
The Central Bureau of Investigation had decided to close the preliminary enquiry (PE) against former ICICI Bank CEO Chanda Kochhar and her husband Deepak Kochhar for want of evidence just weeks before it filed a case against the duo and Videocon group managing director Venugopal Dhoot last week for cheating and conspiracy.


Creditors gives Zee three months’ time to find a buyer
Promoter and chairman of the Essel Group Subhash Chandra got a three-month breather from lenders and creditors to find a buyer for half his stake in the flagship Zee Entertainment Enterprises (ZEE) in a major relief for the Indian entertainment giant.


Debt funds own Rs 8,000 cr Zee shares
The meltdown in the Zee Group stocks is likely to spread to debt funds as well. More than Rs 8,000 crore worth of bonds and debentures issued by group companies are held by 150 debt mutual funds.


F&O traders tank up on Yes Bank with new CEO
Yes Bank could continue its rally since announcing a new CEO last week if huge derivatives bets built by traders recently are anything to go by. The spoiler to the potential rally could be divergence of bad loans identified by RBI and the bank for FY18. Some consolidation before a fresh upmove cannot be ruled out either, given last week’s sharp rally.


FIIs buy Rs 689 crore worth of equities
Foreign portfolio investors (FPIs) bought Rs 689 crore worth of domestic stocks on Friday, data available with NSE suggested. DIIs were net sellers to the tune of Rs 147 crore, data suggested.

Zee stock may provide an opportunity in the short run. In the slightly medium term, more re-rating will take 
  
  
  place when you get the cash back and you see more uptick, Sanjiv Bhasin, Executive VP-Markets & Corporate Affairs, IIFL Securities, tells ET Now.Edited excerpts: 


What are you making of the entire Zee situation and do you think that the clarification would manage to soothe investor nerves?
There were a lot of drama unfolding in Zee. The stock lost 40% and there cannot be problems which were not known. The business is extremely viable and we have seen that even the quarterly results were very good. Creditors giving Zee three months’ extension means that the re-rating will only happen once you really get the money on the table. 

Maybe the deal will take place in a very hurried fashion. If you could lie low and ignore the rhetoric, then at Rs 350 or Rs 320, Zee is definitely a screaming buy. It trades at almost 50% discount to the one year forward multiple, which has never happened in the last three years. We think the OTT platform and the rest will play a very good upside on the media side. However, in the short run, there is a lot of exposure with mutual funds and some of the NBFCs. Even though they have spoken of a hiatus, we hope they follow through with that. All will depend how fast they can get the money on the table.


But given that we are talking about pretty strict timeframe now, just three months, do you think that in terms of the valuations it might not be as lucrative and hence pose a problem for Zee Entertainment?
Correct. So this fall has definitely upset the table for them. We know that they are at the end of the process of finding the right suitor. Maybe they sell slightly more than 50% but there are enough suitors -- whether it is Amazon or Comcast. Everyone wants to get into media or maybe Reliance itself may just be a fence sitter and take a stake, because in the end they are calling the shots on both telecom and media. 

So it is a glass half full, half empty. The stock may be giving you an opportunity in the short run. In the slightly medium term, more re-rating will take place when you get the cash back and you see more uptick once the management clarifies that the debt has been reduced and there is no such unforgettable incidences of collateral selling which really hurts the investors and the mutual funds.

The prospect of a further plunge in the shares of Zee Entertainment and Dish TV, which would deepen the disarray in the Essel Group, has put their managements and investors on edge. Following the sharp selloff on Friday, mutual funds holding debt securities of entities owned by Essel Group’s promoters led by Subhash Chandra face the risk of investments being marked down, leading to an erosion in the value of schemes and sparking a crisis of confidence in the debt market.

While the agreement between Zee promoters and lenders, including mutual funds, to provide a three-month breather while a buyer for Zee Enterprise is found, could provide some respite to the group’s shares, concerns over promoters’ indebtedness would keep investors in debt MFs, which hold the securities of promoter entities, on the tenterhooks.

At least 11 mutual funds — HDFC, Aditya Birla Sun Life and ICICI Prudential among them — have an exposure of Rs 6,600 crore to the Essel Group’s debt securities.

Senior industry executives said a large chunk of this lending has been to promoter entities with shares as collateral. Non-banking finance companies (NBFCs) too have lent to promoter firms.

Zee Enterprises slumped 26 per cent and Dish TV fell 33 per cent on Friday after a news report alleging links between Essel Group and Nityank Infrapower and Multiventures, a company being probed by Serious Fraud Investigation Office (SFIO) for deposits of over Rs 3,000 crore after demonetisation. The slump intensified due to sale of pledged shares, which market participants believe belonged to the promoter group. ECL Finance, lending arm of Edelweiss Group, and IIFL Wealth Finance sold approximately 24.3 million shares of Dish TV, equivalent to 1.3 per cent of company equity, on Friday.



The stock slide prompted group chairman Subhash Chandra to issue a statement in which he apologised to bankers, NBFCs and mutual funds for wrong bets on infrastructure. He also accused “negative forces” of trying to sabotage Zee Entertainment’s strategic sale.

Any further drop in stock values will force lenders and mutual funds to offload pledged shares unless promoters provide fresh equity as collateral. Executives of MFs holding Essel group debt securities met the group management on Saturday to understand how promoters plan to deal with the crisis.

“We’ll continue to follow news flow on companies/group — await details on pledged shares that the company is likely to provide in the next few days, as well as colour on the group’s liquidity/deleveraging process near-term,” said Citi’s Aditya Mathur and Surendra Goyal in a client note after a conference call with analysts over the weekend. “These are likely to have an important bearing on the stocks, possible shareholding changes and play an important role in the consummation of any deal for Zee.”

Many mutual funds and a handful of NBFCs loaned money to at least 16 Essel Group and promoter entities, which pledged shares or property as collateral. Promoters have pledged almost 60 per cent of their 42 per cent in Zee Entertainment. Ratings depend on the quality of the collateral — shares or property. Zee promoters pumped borrowed money into the infrastructure business but losses there hit repayment capability. While the group has been able to service debt through rolling over of loans, the stock crash could make this difficult, forcing promoters to raise money elsewhere.

After the slump, the coverage ratio — the minimum shares required as collateral — for some fund houses has come down to 1.1 times, said a money manager. Hypothetically, if the share price falls by a further 11 per cent on Monday, a mutual fund will not have enough shares to cover its investment in debt securities. Depending on the company, its credit rating and risk profile, mutual funds generally have a cover of 1.5-3 times. When share prices fall, lenders have two options — one is to ask for more collateral from the promoter. The other is to sell some of the shares to maintain the coverage ratio. It could not be ascertained if mutual funds sold shares of the company on Friday.

“It is one of those peculiar cases of the company being healthy while promoters are heavily indebted. Stress at promoter level is impacting the company,” said a senior executive at a large mutual fund owning a sizeable chunk of Zee shares and with exposure to the group's debt instruments.

Friday’s crash in Zee and Dish TV prompted some distributors and financial advisors to ask rich clients over the weekend to pull money out of mutual fund schemes with exposure to the group’s debt. These instruments are held across various credit risk funds, dynamic bond funds and corporate bond funds.

“If the stock price continues its slide, we could see a lot of redemptions from HNIs (high net worth investors). If the fund house does not write down its investment, it could affect the remaining investors in the same,” said the research head of a private banking outfit.

In the recent past, investors have suffered losses in debt mutual fund schemes, which fully wrote down investments in Infrastructure Leasing & Financial Services (IL&FS). A few other schemes have written off a fourth of their investments in SPV of road projects of IL&FS.

NEW DELHI: Many foreign brokerages have maintained their buy ratings on Zee Entertainment as the stock now trades at a deep discount to long-term averages following Friday’s 27 per cent plunge. 

Nomura India said there is no change in business fundamentals after Friday's correction in the stock price. A large part of the correction in the stock price was in the futures and options segment, and actual deliveries were much lower, it said. 

The stock took a beating on Friday on a report suggesting the company’s alleged link with Nityank lnfrapower, which is under SFIO investigation. The company has strongly denied the report and on Sunday said it has reached a deal with lenders on not invoking shares of the company if the stock price falls further.

Deutsche Bank in a note said promoters' intention to sell up to 50 per cent of their shareholding to a strategic partner, which is expected to be completed in March or April, will be positive for minority shareholders.

“Of the three Infra assets, one deal is done (expect funds to come in very shortly - weeks/months). Solar and road asset deals too should see full consummation to happen in 3-6 months. EV of the three infra asset sale is upwards of Rs 20,000 crore with equity value of Rs 8,000-9,000 crore. Sale of the Infra assets would remove a significant part of the pledge, only a small amount would be left to take care of,” the brokerage said.

On Monday, the scrip rose 14.29 per cent to hit a high of Rs 365 on the BSE. The promoter group of the company has said the stake sale process in Zee is at an advanced stage and will be met within the stated timeline.

The management on Monday said 96-97 per cent of the lenders have agreed not to invoke shares if the shares fall further. After the agreement, the company has not pledged further shares as collateral after Friday’s sharp fall, said CEO Punit Goenka said in an investor call.

There is standstill on part of lenders for now, Goenka said. The management said stake sale in Zee will not be hit by recent developments.

Following the revocation of company shares on Friday, promoter holding has dropped 60 basis points to 41 per cent, the management said. 

Essel Group has pledged 59 per cent of its Zee ownership (effective 25 per cent) to group lenders, CLSA said.

“While pledging of Zee shares is not new, its rise from 42 per cent in December 2013 to 59 per cent in December 2018 and Zee’s stock price fall have exacerbated risk of pledges being invoked,” CLSA said. 

That said, the brokerage has retained its buy call on the stock as it sees valuations compelling at 16 times FY20 PE, a 45 per cent discount to 10-year average PE.

Deutsche Bank values Zee at 28 times March 2020 earnings, a 15 per cent discount to its five-year average trading multiple and has a target price of Rs 575 on the stock.

CLSA said Zee’s valuations look compelling after the sharp fall, adding that it sees 19 per cent earnings CAGR over 2019-21.

Shares of Zee Entertainment Enterprises rebounded 16.6 per cent Monday, after the Essel Group said it obtained an assurance from lenders that Friday’s rout in the group flagship’s market price would not lead to declaration of a default. Shares of other group companies also gained sharply after managing director Punit Goenka, in a pre-market call with analysts, reiterated that there was no change in the growth guidance of the company and that its stake-sale plans were on track.

Zee management went into a fire-fighting mode over the weekend after the shares tanked 26 per cent, the steepest ever during a day’s trade, on Friday, even as chairman Subhash Chandra made a dramatic statement claiming that “negative forces” were trying to sabotage his efforts to find a buyer for Zee’s stake and apologised to investors for what he called his strategic mistakes. 

Promoters and top executives reached out to analysts and media over the past two days, as well as held a series of investor calls to allay fears of erosion in the company’s market value.

Chandra had last month announced that the promoters were looking for a strategic buyer for half their stake in Zee. This was to help in its global expansion and repayment of loans. There was a fear that lenders would sell shares pledged by the promoters if the value fell further.

Zee shares closed at Rs 372.50, up Rs 53.15, Monday on the Bombay Stock Exchange, while Dish TV gained 5.5 per cent to close at Rs 24 and Essel Propack rose 10 per cent to Rs 107. 

The benchmark Sensex ended 1 per cent lower.

While analysts are optimistic about Zee’s business prospects, they also flagged concerns over promoters' indebtedness.

Although the business remains robust, the promoter entity needs to reduce debt, said Edelweiss in a note to investors, adding: “We believe that the emerged developments will tone down the management’s potential to realise the value in business.” The brokerage cut its one-year target price on the Zee stock by 20 per cent to Rs 489, but maintained the ‘buy’ rating after the recent fall in the price.

Sharekhan, the retail broking arm of BNP Paribas, downgraded the stock to ‘hold’ from ‘buy’, citing the ongoing developments. 

“Although the fundamentals of the Zee group remain intact, the vulnerability of the stock has gone up,” said Gaurav Dua, head of research. “There could be a derating in the stock due to the ongoing developments, which could change the price-to-earnings multiples of the stock.”


DEAL WITH LENDERS 
Just before the opening bell, Goenka, who is also Zee’s chief executive, informed analysts about reaching an agreement with lenders where they agreed that they would not declare default due the fall in the share price on Friday. He said they had given the promoters more time to reduce their stake in the flagship company.

The new terms with lenders include completion of the deal and loan repayment in a time-bound manner.

“We have got a timeframe which extends beyond the April 2019 deadline that we had committed towards the stake sale,” Goenka said on the call. “We will now reengage with the prospective buyers and I'm confident that we should be able to do it in within the timeline we have set for ourselves.”

ET reported on Monday that lenders had given Chandra three months to find a buyer.

When asked about what Goenka meant by reengaging with buyers, a Zee spokesperson told ET that in view of the drop in the company’s share price, it was natural for additional players to find the deal attractive than before. Hence, the dialogues with them would certainly get initiated “while discussions with the shortlisted partners, on the other hand, are anyways in a good progress,” he said.

According to Goenka, Friday’s drop in the share price would not have any bearing on the deal, as the “intrinsic value of the asset remains the same”. There are “multiple suitors” for the stake, he added.

The company refused to comment on whether promoters would be willing to sell more than 50 per cent of their shares, calling it too early.

Meanwhile, Zee said it filed a defamation case against the online publication that wrote about alleged links between the Essel Group and a company that was under scrutiny for large cash deposits during or after demonetisation. 

Goenka said the Essel Group and Zee had nothing to do with the allegations.

Goenka also said the promoters had pledged shares only in India. The management assured lenders that proceeds from any deal will first go to them and only after that the promoters will claim their share, he said.

Subhash Chandra, the grains-to-media tycoon, is facing a storm just after he set his eyes on bigger things and decided to divest up to 50% of promoter holding in India’s leading entertainment company Zee Entertainment Enterprises Ltd. (ZEEL). Shares of Zee and Essel group companies shares were pounded on Friday. Zee Enterprises slumped 26 per cent and Dish TV fell 33 per cent after a news report alleging links between Essel Group and Nityank Infrapower and Multiventures, a company being probed by Serious Fraud Investigation Office (SFIO) for deposits of over Rs 3,000 crore after demonetisation. 

This was followed by a dramatic mea culpa by Chandra and then a three-month breather to him from lenders and creditors to find a buyer.


The Nityank affair
In the eye of the storm is a company called Nityank Infrapower and Multiventures which is being probed by Serious Fraud Investigation Office (SFIO). ET reported in December the legal tussle between Essel and Videocon over Nityank. It all started when a merger between the DTH arms of Videocon and Essel groups, which took place in March 2018, landed in the Delhi High Court. 

In a case filed on 31 August of 2018 a Videocon group company has claimed that Essel group unlawfully invoked pledges on certain Videocon D2H shares that were placed in their custody. 

The legal tussle between Essel and Videocon started after Nityank approached NCLT to prevent allotment of shares to Videocon group company Domebell in the merged Dish TVNSE 4.46 % entity on the grounds that it had a pledge on Videocon D2H shares owned by Domebell. Nityank claimed the shares should be allotted to itself. 

Domebell and a group of other Videocon companies such as Electroparts later approached the Delhi high court on 31 August this year claiming that Nityank is an Essel group company and had unlawfully invoked a pledge on Videocon D2H shares that were placed as security with it in the event a merger with Dish TV were to fall through. 

Domebell and a group of other Videocon companies such as Electroparts later approached the Delhi high court on 31 August this year claiming that Nityank is an Essel group company and had unlawfully invoked a pledge on Videocon D2H shares that were placed as security with it in the event a merger with Dish TV were to fall through. It sought an injunction from the court restraining the allotment of shares to Nityank in the merged Dish TV entity. The court granted the stay which was valid till 9 September. The case has been pending.


Why is SFIO probing Nityank?
The SFIO is investigating companies that made huge cash deposits and withdrawals during and soon after demonetization. The ministry of corporate affairs (MCA) has asked the Serious Fraud Investigation Office (SFIO) to probe 57 shell companies on the basis of reports by regional directors of the office of the Registrar of Companies (RoCs). 

A TOI report dated 31 July 2018 stated Nityank (formerly known as Dreamline Manpower Solutions) had come under the scrutiny of the fraud watchdog after it deposited and withdrew large amounts of cash with Yes Bank in the aftermath of demonetisation. 

Though the company did not respond to official queries from ET, sources close to Nityank told ET that the transactions were "legal" and the SFIO had been provided relevant explanations.

In a response to emailed queries from ET, Essel group had denied any association with Nityank. “Nityank Infrapower and Multiventures Ltd. is not an Essel Group Company and all the allegations are completely baseless and infructuous,” a spokesperson said in response. Recently, ZEEL said in a regulatory filing that involvement of Essel Group entities in the the SFIO investigation against Nityank was being done only with "malicious intent" and "legal action as advised" was being initiated in this regard. 

Videocon gave a different picture in court filings. In a letter written to the SFIO on July 2, 2018 and subsequently submitted to the court, Videocon group company, Hindustan Oil Ventures (HOV) has said that Nityank subscribed to its debentures worth Rs. 1,626 crore on behalf of the Essel group as advance payment for the shares that the Subhash Chandra group was buying in the Videocon D2H business.

HOV claimed that Nityank entered into back to back share purchase and "letter agreements" at the time the merger was being negotiated with Essel. As per the agreements, Essel and Videocon would nominate a company each to facilitate the transfer of the advance payment. Further, Nityank’s filing with the Registrar of Companies (ROC) show that it had provided security for loans worth approximately Rs. 1,600 crore taken by three Essel group companies — RPW Projects, Pan India Network Infravest and Mumbai WTR —in 2017. It furnished HOV debentures as security for these loans.


The apology
After the group stocks crashed, Chandra issued a dramatic and unusual statement claiming that “negative forces” were trying to sabotage Zee Entertainment’s strategic sale, while acknowledging that he had committed mistakes. He apologised to his bankers, non-banking finance companies and mutual funds. Chandra’s ‘open letter’ did not mention the Nityank issue. Instead, he said he was compelled to apologise to bankers, NBFCs and mutual funds as he had not lived up to their expectations. 

He said wrong bets in the infrastructure sector combined with the meltdown of IL&FS had resulted in “Rs 4,000 crore to Rs 5,000 crore” of losses. The wrong infrastructure bets had left the company with non-performing assets, he admitted.

Chandra admitted that the ballooning debt was also a result of some other decisions, notably the acquisition of Videocon D2H. He termed the acquisition a key error that cost him and his brother Jawahar Goel a “fortune”. 

One reason behind Chandra's open letter apologising to the lenders and seeking their patience was that some of the lenders, who have a pledge on the promoter family stock, had sold about 6.5 million shares in the Friday carnage. 


Finally, the breather
Chandra has reached an agreement with lenders, under which the latter wouldn’t declare an event of default due to the steep fall in share prices. A prolonged meeting between the lenders and the promoters took place over the weekend after the stocks crashed. On Sunday evening, Essel said the lenders had agreed not to trigger “any event of default declared due to the steep fall in price”. “As a result, there will be synergy and co-operation among lenders, leading to a unified approach,” the statement added. Lenders drew comfort from reiteration by the promoters for a speedy resolution through a strategic sale in a time-bound manner, the statement said.


The Jio buzz
Mukesh Ambani-led Reliance Jio is likely to enter the fray to buy half of promoter Chandra’s stake in ZEEL, according to a Business Standard report based on information from sources. Jio will be pitted against international names such as Amazon, Apple, Tencent, and Alibaba, which have shown interest. Chandra and family along with its advisors met in Mumbai over the Diwali weekend last year and decided to offload up to half of its promoter holding of about 42% in flagship ZEEL as part of a "strategic review of its businesses in the changing global media landscape".

The entertainment sector is being revolutionised by convergence and over-the-top (OTT) services and this where Chandra might want to focus in future. In October, ZEEL. became the first Indian entertainment company to take its OTT video service, ZEE5, to over 190 countries.

ZEEL's managing director & CEO Punit Goenka had said the company was looking for global strategic partner to foray into virtual reality, augmented reality, Internet of Things and 3D printing to build a robust platform beyond traditional audio-visual content. The talk of Jio's interest shows that the promoters are now also looking for domestic buyers.

NEW DELHI: Domestic equity benchmark Sensex plunged over 368 points on Monday to close at 35,656 amid across-the-board selling as market sentiment turned volatile ahead of the Union Budget, which is widely believed to have some populist announcements. There was heavy selling pressure on the banking, auto and consumer durables counters. 

Weak global cues in the form of poor industrial output print for China also weighed in on investor sentiment. Nifty tumbled 119 points to end at 10,661. 

Midcaps and smallcaps suffered more than the largecap benchmarks, plunging up to 2 per cent. 


Let’s a look at the key highlights of Monday's session: 


Rs 1.80 lakh crore wiped off
Monday’s mayhem eroded investor wealth by Rs 1.80 lakh crore in a single day. The cumulative market capitalisation of all BSE-listed stocks declined to Rs 1,38,99,677 crore from Rs 1,40,80,491 crore at the end of Friday. 


Zee has a stellar show
With a whopping 16.64 per cent gain, shares of Zee Entertainment closed the day at Rs 372 on BSE. The scrip saw a smart turnaround after the company said it had reached a deal with the lenders on pledged shares and 97 per cent of the lenders have agreed not to revoke shares should the stock fall further. Media reports suggested Reliance Jio has shown interest in buying half of promoter stake in Zee Entertainment. Some global players such as Amazon, Apple, Tencent, Alibaba, AT&T, Singtel, Comcast and Sony Pictures, too, are said to be in the race. 


L&T gains on Q3 show
L&T shares climbed 1.17 per cent to Rs 1,300, buoyed by healthy December quarter numbers that the capital goods major unveiled post market hours on Friday. The company reported Rs 2,042 crore profit for the October-December period over Rs 1,490 crore in Q3 FY18. Many brokerages, including Macquarie, Credit Suisse and Phillip Capital, have expressed faith on the company’s performance. 


More pain for Graphite India, HEG
Shares of HEG closed 20 per cent down at Rs 2,194 and those of Graphite India 9.30 per cent down at Rs 500.85 after having touched 52-week lows at Rs 2,194 and 470, respectively. This was Graphite India’s eighth consecutive fall, while HEG fell for the third straight session. Graphite stocks have been under pressure of late amid concerns related to imports from China and anti-dumping duty. 


Wockhardt cracks 7% on poor Q3 numbers
The pharma firm reported widening of its consolidated net loss to Rs 71.11 crore for December quarter. The company had posted a net loss of Rs 40.76 crore for the corresponding period of the previous financial year. The stock closed 7.04 per cent down at Rs 444. 


Jet shares decline 3%
Extending losses into the second session in a row, shares of Jet Airways (India) closed 3.06 per cent down at Rs 245.40 after the company said it was seeking shareholders’ approval for converting existing debt into shares. In a regulatory filing with NSE, Jet said it would seek consent of shareholders to convert the whole or part of the outstanding loans into shares or convertible instruments or other securities of the company. 


Canara Bank plunges 5%
The public sector lender reported a 152.5 per cent year-on-year (YoY) surge in profit for December quarter. Provisions and contingencies fell 26.04 per cent YoY. However, at first glance, the Street appeared dissatisfied with the numbers and the stock plunged 5.23 per cent to close at Rs 240.30 on BSE. 


Banks, financials hit hard
Most bank and financial stocks closed the day with deep cuts. Shares of DHFL (down 11.64 per cent), Indiabulls Ventures (down 9.34 per cent), YES Bank (down 5.46 per cent), ICICI Bank (down 3.82 per cent) and IndusInd Bank (down 3.10 per cent) were among the top laggards. Out of total 10 components of BSE Bankex, only one - City Union Bank (up 0.93 per cent) - closed with gains. In the BSE Finance index, 104 stocks suffered losses and only 13 ended in the green. Both sectoral indices fell up to 2 per cent. 


IT, Teck indices buck the trend
BSE Basic Materials and BSE Healthcare fell 2.09 per cent and 2.08 per cent, respectively, leading the pack of sectoral losers. On the other hand, BSE Teck (up 0.80 per cent) and IT (up 0.42 per cent) indices finished on top despite the selloff, thanks to gains in shares of Zee Entertainment (up 16.64 per cent), Bharti Infratel (up 2.27 per cent), TCS (up 1.71 per cent), Tech Mahindra (up 0.97 per cent) and Wipro (up 0.57 per cent). 


138 stocks signal fall
Momentum indicator moving average convergence divergence, or MACD, showed bearish crossovers on 138 counters on BSE. Among them were Infibeam Avenues, BPCL, Hindalco, Vedanta, Sun Pharma and Bajaj Finance. On the other hand, Persistent Systems, Thyrocare Tech, Shilchar Technologies, CJ Gelatine and Provestment Services were among 27 stocks that showed positive crossovers on BSE.
