NEW DELHI: Flareup of tensions between India and Pakistan turned investors jittery on Dalal Street on Wednesday, causing equity benchmarks Sensex and Nifty to end in the red and extend the losing run into the second consecutive session. 

The market witnessed high volatility a day ahead of the expiry of February futures and options contracts. Volatility index India VIX jumped 12.24 per cent. 

After opening in the green and surging nearly 400 points, Sensex tumbled 238 points to touch an intraday low of 35,735 after reports of a faceoff between Indian and Pakistani forces. 

The 30-share index eventually closed 68 points, or 0.19 per cent, lower at 35,905, with 17 stocks ending in the green. Nifty shed 29 points, or 0.26 per cent, to end at 10,806.

The BSE Midcap and Smallcap indices, however, managed to buck the trend, and close 0.40 per cent and 0.17 per cent higher, respectively.

We are not expecting an immediate bounce but structurally, a broader market performance can be expected, said 
Pankaj Pandey, HoR, ICICIdirect.com, in an interview with ET Now.Edited excerpts: 

The markets have put up a fairly brave face in the light of Indian Air Force bombing terror camps in Pakistan. How do you believe the overall trend is for the markets? Do we have the legs to take this sort of move higher given that the 10,800 mark was maintained?
The prospects of a stable government are far brighter now and which is why we would want to believe that probably there is a chance for a broader market performance. Up till now, the defensives have been largely holding ground this year -- mostly IT, FMCG and pharma. We would expect that since the overall inflation trajectory is going to be a little soft, it will also boost interest rate cut prospects. So, we are expecting another 50 bps rate cut. 

Besides the defensives, we would expect that the infra players will also benefit going forward. Recently, the market breadth has also been quite decent. But probably for the next month or so, we would expect the market to be in a range, probably at 10,800-11,100. So, we are not expecting an immediate bounce but structurally, a broader market performance can be expected.

 Otherwise, macros and earnings have been quite decent and that will support the overall improvement. But the biggest anxiety is elections. If the prospects of a stable government brightens up, we would expect markets to do well.


Are you saying that till the time election verdict is out, markets will not go anywhere? If that was the situation, then why do we have a pre-election rally every time before elections? 
Largely what we have seen in the past three instances has been that in runup to elections, the defensives have done well. Post elections, we have seen a good broader market performance. Last time also, there was decent prospect of a stable government. This time, earlier there was a bit of anxiety and there was an expectation of a hung parliament. If we get a stable government, a broader market performance can be seen post elections. 

We will have to see how things sort of pan out. For the next few days, I would expect market to remain range-bound. But somebody has to look at buying. Buying before elections make better sense because overall macroeconomic setup remains pretty good domestically. Globally things getting slightly better. Overall, that improves the prospects for our market. 


The auto index has underperformed for quite a while. Investor sentiment seems to have been hit. Can we see some demand stability kicking in and valuations improving? Would it make sense to remain in auto space now?
We have a negative view on the overall auto space. While we expect there will be some improvement in overall volume, steel prices are still at higher level and there is a prospect of increasing steel prices. We do not expect margin recovery for the broader auto as overall. Globally, things are still fluid on the auto front. One can look at certain pockets. For example, two-wheelers, which might be a beneficiary of direct income transfer which the government has started doing and there also the valuations are quite reasonable at 13-14 times. That is one pocket people can look at though I do not expect a recovery in auto as a pack.


It seems the Future Retail deal with Amazon is going to be announced next month. Amazon is now seeking a 10% stake in Future Retail which could be worth about Rs 2,000 crore. What would it imply for the Future Group?
We do not have a coverage on the Future Group but overall the way e-commerce guidelines have come up, largely it is positive for domestic players. What we like is something like Trent and ABFRL within the retail space. In both the cases, we are seeing decent margin recovery plus Trent is looking to ramp up the store count to about 30 odd on annual basis compared to 7-8 odd which they were doing earlier. Similarly for ABFRL there is a good margin improvement what we have seen across so these stocks which we like in the overall retail as a space.


How do you see the story of Zee Entertainment shaping up?
We have a negative view on the media space but we think the price decline in Zee is substantial and expect it to happen at six months’ average prices, which is above Rs 500. We would expect the price recovery to pan out. 

But globally, there are enough disruptions happening in media sector and that is why we are slightly sceptical in this space. Except for the radio as a segment, most of the other segments -- print or broadcasting -- look stressed. Besides this, the multiplex as a segment looks pretty attractive to us. We are quite positive on both Inox as well as PVR.

By 
Arun Mukherjee & Soumya Malani 


(Kolkata’s Arun Mukherjee, who dropped out of college to turn a full-time investor at an early age, and Soumya Malani, a London School of Economics alumnus, have come to be known as smallcap aficionados within India’s investor community. They would show up at most AGMs, visit the remotest factories of a company and go chasing end-users to understand their experience with a product in their passionate hunt for good smallcaps. Arun and Soumya share their experiences with such companies from the ground in this space every now and then.)
‘India is not for sale.’ Remember the inspirational lines of Subhas Chandra Goel while rejecting Rupert Murdoch’s takeover bid? It’s an extraordinary rags-to-riches story of a high school dropout from Haryana, who went on to pioneer our country’s first satellite Hindi channel Zee TV.

The self-made media tycoon has created massive wealth for shareholders since its IPO in 1993. Today, Zee Entertainment is among the highest revenue grossers in the Indian media industry. The group controls 20 per cent share of India’s traditional television viewing market. But of late everything is not going right for Goel and Zee. He recently penned an emotional letter concerning everyone linked to Zee Entertainment.

Let’s do a reality check on the business.

A plethora of unfortunate events rocked the business. Allegations of Zee’s association with Nityank Infra, which is being probed by the SFIO for demonetisation deposit worth Rs 3,000 crore, selling of pledge shares by lenders, IL&FS debt default leading to a lending squeeze, delay in strategic stake sell in Zee, all have cumulatively resulted in headwinds that have made the company stock tank 40 per cent, before paring some of the losses.

Operationally, Zee’s core business is on a sound footing; the problem lies with its group companies. A classic case of a blue chip firm with little idea to reinvest its high cash flows, resulting in such “di-worsification”. The good part is that there won’t be any further sale of pledge shares by the lenders for a few months; the deadline we believe has been extended beyond April 2019.

Everything now boils down to a stake sale to ensure smooth functioning of the company. Though the management has hinted that the stake sale will happen at a price much higher than the current market price as the strategic investor or set of investors “believe in the intrinsic value of the company,” but we have doubts such a deal can materialise.

Why would someone pay a higher price when you are in a soup? When it’s the last resort for your survival? Rather, you would be squeezed to the core as far valuation or stake sale price is concerned. The bargaining power in such a scenario, as we all know, shifts to the buyer from the seller. Empirical evidence suggests whenever a company has gone into a limbo, the mess gets murkier and resolution often takes a lot of time, which further derails the business.

For most of its life space, Zee shares have traded on an average PE multiple of over 30. Considering its thrust on digital revolution and with at the current PE of 17 times FY20 earnings, valuations definitely looks reasonable. However, as they say, it’s 90 per cent is psychology and 10 per cent knowledge in investing. A stock that may look as a screaming ‘buy’ can be your reason to scream in frustration later. Market pays a premium for certainty in the affairs of a business. What scares us is the consensus bet on a speedy resolution. Almost every shareholder or fund manager we talk to believes a deal is inevitable. What if there’s no deal?

Remember, the lenders will have a limit to their patience. Mr Market has an uncanny habit of ridiculing the majority. Also, it would be prudent to note that the general election is approaching fast. The opposition Congress isn’t a big fan of the Zee Group, as we all know. If the party manages the unthinkable and wrests power at the Centre, things might get really tough for Zee.

Often, it’s way more important to fathom “what can go wrong” rather than a “what would go right” scenario. Playing the role of devil’s advocate here, we feel until we have a strategic stake sale deal, Zee will face a lot of uncertainties, leading to continuous pressure on the stock.

By Rajiv Ranjan Singh

Lending to promoters has been on the rise in India. The estimated value of pledged shares by promoters to various lenders in the current fiscal year is Rs. 1.2 lakh crore, an increase of around 60% over the last year. This indicates significant increase in leverage. Traditionally, promoters can pledge shares to banks as well as NBFCs.

Why do promoters pledge shares? To begin with, promoters (legally, a person with a controlling stake in a company) own most listed companies in India. When promoters need to raise funds, they can easily raise money by selling their shares in the company. However, this typically has a negative impact on the share price in the stock market. So, instead of selling shares, many promoters raise funds by pledging shares to a lender and borrow against them. In 2009, SEBI mandated public disclosure of promoters selling or pledging their shares.

Lending against securities is risky. That is why the Reserve Bank of India places certain restrictions on banks and NBFC’s for loans against shares. The rules relate to margin requirements that need to be maintained, as well as system wide exposure. The Reserve Bank of India actively monitors these loans. This is to maintain the stability of the financial system.

In the event of a market fall, a margin call would be triggered. If the promoters fail to fund the margin call, the creditor would need to sell shares. This can further trigger a decline in the share price, and the creditor may face a loss in this scenario.

This is where innovative structures have surfaced; several debt mutual funds have created structures to lend money to promoters against their equity shares. Debt mutual funds have extended loans to promoters, typically by purchasing bonds issued by the holding company controlled by the promoter.

Mutual Funds have been actively involved in backing promoter loans with shares/operational assets in their search of yields. Equity shares offer quick liquidity than other fixed assets, but they can be risky if the underlying price of the stock suddenly decreases. Usually, the collateral (equity shares) value is substantially higher than the loan amount to guard against any correction in the stock value.

The default by the IL&FS has turned the spotlight on the NBFC sector, as well as financing by pledging of shares. IL&FS Transport Networks, a listed company of the IL&FS Group, has seen its share price decline by 91% from its 52-week high. The promoters of the company had pledged 98% of their holding, which equalled 71.9% of total outstanding shares. IL&FS Transport Networks are among the IL&FS Group companies that have defaulted on debt.

Fears regarding lending against shares by mutual funds using the structure we have highlighted earlier arose when mutual funds sought a standstill agreement with lenders and did not sell pledged shares. It emerged that the holding companies had borrowed funds, pledging shares worth 59% of Zee Entertainment. The figure was 45.7% a year ago, indicating an increase in leverage. Aditya Birla Sun Life Mutual Fund, among other fund houses, had a large exposure.

The concerns are high for some other companies, too. For example, Reliance Capital’s promoters had pledged 74.5% of their shares as on December 2018. Similarly, Bajaj Consumer Care’s promoters had pledged 70.5% of their holdings.

Pledging of shares is higher among promoters of mid- and small-cap companies, where pledging totals Rs 77,000 crore worth of shares in FY19, which is 62% of the total value of the promoter shares pledged in the same period. So far in 2019, more than Rs 16,000 crore worth of shares has been pledged by the promoters. Debt mutual funds have been active participants.

Because of these risks, SEBI is reportedly considering tightening disclosure norms. Mutual funds are essentially offering a loan against shares when they are buying commercial paper of the holding companies. The regulator is also reportedly considering framing rules for concentration risk as well. While the regulator has given some forbearance in the current crisis, this is a temporary measure we believe not to precipitate a crisis. In the coming months new regulations are likely. While Indian listed companies have made great progress in terms of regulatory driven improvement in transparency and timely disclosures, this event highlights that progress needs to be made in some other areas.

This is an also a near-term overhang on equity markets. We would be wary of investing in shares where promoters have a substantial pledge. This can be a systemic risk as well as outstanding loans against shares to promoters is roughly Rs 2 lakh crore. However, we believe that the right policy response along with liquidity assistance by RBI can prevent a crisis.


(Rajiv Ranjan Singh is CEO - Stock Broking, Karvy)

NEW DELHI: Domestic equities extended the winning streak into a third successive session on Wednesday, thanks to gains in shares of select heavyweights such as Reliance Industries, ICICI Bank, HDFC and ITC.

Weakness in crude oil price influenced the mood of investors, while improving prospects of Modi’s return to power in the 2019 election also lifted investor mood.

Sensex logged a healthy gain of 194 points, or 0.53 per cent, to finish at 36,636, while Nifty50 settled 66 points, or 0.60 per cent, higher at 11,053. 

Midcaps and smallcaps rose in sync with Sensex; BSE Midcap index rose 0.49 per cent and BSE Smallcap index 0.97 per cent.

We walk you through the key highlights of Wednesday's session:


ITC gains on price hikeShares of ITC closed 0.99 per cent at Rs 285.45 after the firm increased prices of three cigarette brands - Bristol, Flake Excel and Capstan. The move is expected to boost its margins. Brokerage ICICIdirect said the price hike would help the firm grow margins. Bristol, Flake Excel and Capstan account for 11-13 per cent of total cigarette volumes.


DHFL jumps 11%Shares of Dewan Housing Finance Corporation (DHFL) surged 11.04 per cent to Rs 148 after an auditor report found little substance in Cobrapost allegations and said the company did not create shell companies to divert funds. However, it did deviated from internal lending practices which exposed a significant amount of loans to risk of turning sour, Reuters reported, quoting the audit report. 


Grasim gains after Soktas India buyShares of Grasim Industries closed 1.44 per cent up at Rs 819.95 after the Birla group flagship firm signed an agreement to acquire Soktas India from its Turkish promoters for Rs 165 crore. 


Wipro shares climb 2 per centShares of Wipro closed 2.05 per cent up at Rs 278.30 after the scrip turned ex-bonus in the 1:3 ratio. Wipro in February received approval from majority shareholders for issue of bonus shares and to increase authorised share capital. 


ITC, Raymond above 200 DMAsTata Steel BSL, ITC, Raymond, Jammu and Kashmir Bank, Ashoka Buildcon, Edelweiss Bank, Deepak Nitrite, PTC India, Jubilant Industries and Jubilant Foodworks were among the stocks that witnessed positive breakouts and traded above their 200-DMAs. On the other hand, Bosch, Bank of India, Zee Entertainment, Panacea Biotec, Ansal Housing, Britannia Industries and Nestle (India) were among the stocks that traded below their 200-DMAs.


Richer & richerThe three-day rally in stocks made investors richer by Rs 4.67 lakh crore, as total market capitalisation of BSE-listed firms shot up to Rs 1,45,08,678 crore at the end of Wednesday from Rs 1,40,41,530 crore last Thursday. On Wednesday alone, the overall market capitalisation rose by Rs 84,000 crore. 


274 stocks hit upper circuitsAs many as 274 BSE stocks, including Tata Steel, Kwality, Aban Offshore, Coral India Finance & Housing, Shriram EPC and Weizmann, hit upper circuits. On the flip side, Jaypee Infratech, Gyscoal Alloys, Cyber Media (India), SAB Events & Governance Now Media, Atlas Jewellery India and Oasis Tradelink were among 180 stocks that hit lower circuit limits.


Spurt in open interestWipro, with a change of 61.92 per cent, led the pack of stocks that witnessed the biggest spurt in open interest (OI) on NSE. It was followed by Birlasoft (53.44 per cent), Repco Home Finance (38.64 per cent), Power Grid Corporation (36.10 per cent) and IDBI Bank (35.54 per cent). 


Auto pack lone sectoral loserThe BSE Auto index fell 0.24 per cent to finish as the lone sectoral loser. Among the 16 index stocks, eight closed the day with gains while an equal number settled with losses. Tata Motors (down 2.81 per cent), Bharat Forge (down 1.65 per cent), Hero MotoCorp (down 1.10 per cent) and Maruti Suzuki (down 0.78 per cent) were among the top losers. 


84 stocks signal potential riseMomentum indicator moving average convergence divergence, or MACD, showed bullish crossovers on 84 counters on BSE. Among them were Axis Bank, Bata India, Astral Poly Technik, Eveready Industries, Bata India, Aurobindo Pharma and Amara Raja Batteries. On the other hand, Cipla, Khaitan (India), GTPL Hathaway, Sahara Housing Finance Corporation and Capital India Finance were among 15 stocks that saw bearish crossovers.

The strategic stake sale of Zee Entertainment Enterprises will likely be at a premium and may not see any management change post sale, said CLSA.

The foreign brokerage has retained a buy rating on the stock with a target price of Rs 670 as the stock is trading at a 15 per cent discount to 10-year average valuations. 

Zee’s stock has rallied nearly 50 per cent since the January 2019 lows due to a potential strategic stake sale by promoters which will help the Essel Group deleverage. 

"This rally will also reduce the risk of further invocation of pledges by lenders and will help promoters sell a lower stake. Further, a blue sky for minority shareholders would be no change in Zee’s core management team and arm’s length business dealing with new partner," said CLSA. 

In a scenario that promoters would look to repay at least 80 per cent of Rs 13,500 crore loan against shares via the strategic stake sale, Essel Group will have to sell at least 20 per cent stake in Zee, said CLSA. However, given that a premium is likely, in case transaction takes place at 20 per cent premium to current market price, promoters could pay off entire loan against shares by selling 25 per cent stake in Zee, it added.

Last week, the world’s largest private residential ship docked in Mumbai. Called ‘The World’, it has 165 luxury residences on board, owned by wealthy businessmen from across the world. The owners often spend a part of the year on the ship and others can book the residences during the remaining period. Only housekeeping comes free on the ship run by a Florida-based company flying the flag of The Bahamas.

Of the 165 residences, some are owned by Indian-origin businessmen. The ship travels across the world — the route decided after a vote among the residents — and offers entertainment, sports and a choice of half-a-dozen restaurants. This year, the ship made four stops in India before sailing for Oman. A businessperson, who recently attended a dinner onboard the cruise ship, says there was a palpable interest among the residents about India as a manufacturing hub, and some said they were already buying more from India than from China.


 The Nikkei Purchasing Manager’s Index that indicates the degree of confidence in the manufacturing sector also signals a revival in factory output in India. For February, the PMI was at 54.3 — a 14-month high. It has been going up for three months now.

Not only manufacturing PMI but services PMI too along with overall business confidence index have moved up in the last three months. Predictions are that the indices will go higher as the country enters poll season.

But the question is: can India’s private sector make the most of these tailwinds? And is it in a position to do so? Will this lead to fresh capital investments?

Consider the impact of a significant drop in GDP growth rate. Economic growth for the current financial year touched a six-quarter low of 6.6% in the September-December period, dropping from 8.2% in April-June and 7.1% in July-September.

Ajit Ranade, chief economist at the Aditya Birla Group, told ET Magazine that he is seeing signs of revival of the capital expenditure cycle of companies in India but there are some drags such as a slowdown in China. Businessmen are adept at making the most of a chequered field but only if their businesses are fighting fit. Many marquee names of India Inc are in no shape to start big investments.




Rise & Fall with TidesA crackdown by the Reserve Bank of India on loan defaulters has virtually changed the face of India Inc.

Consider Essar steel, Reliance Communications, Electrosteel Steels, Bhushan Steel and Jaypee Group. All are facing action at the National Company Law Tribunal. ArcelorMittal is also set to take over Essar Steel. Or take Jet Airways, the one-time leader in Indian aviation which is now unable to manage its debt burden of `8,000 crore and contemplating a change in management. Around 23 of its aircraft — nearly a fifth of its fleet — have been grounded by lessors. Or consider Vedanta and its problems with its copper smelter plant in Tamil Nadu and its iron ore mining operations in Goa.


 The Chinese slowdown Ranade points to, for instance, may open up opportunities for Indian companies, it is also creating its own share of problems. Some Indian businesses were running on the back of the Chinese boom too.

Tata Motors’ scrip price rose and has now slipped as the performance of JLR, its subsidiary that accounts for the bulk of the automaker’s valuation, has slackened. In market capitalisation, Tata Motors tops the list of the Nifty companies with the biggest drops in the last two years.

R Gopalakrishnan, a former director of Tata Sons and author of several management books since retirement, says the problems of India Inc began with a period of hubris and misjudgment, where meaningless league tables of the ‘richest’ and the ‘biggest’ were bandied about.

“When the tides rose, every ship rose,” says Gopalakrishnan, recalling a 2012 speech by Prime Minister Manmohan Singh where he called for the release of “animal spirits” in business. “If you are on the dance floor, you have to keep tapping your feet. But suddenly, the music stopped and the carpet too was pulled out,” says Gopalakrishnan.


 Industrialist Harsh Goenka calls the decade-ago period as one of “adventurism” and says the action following implementation of the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code is the best thing to have happened to India’s economy. “No promoter thought he would lose his company and many also created hurdles in the process.” Goenka says he expected capacity utilisation in India’s manufacturing sector to hit 85% by this time. (It is around 75% now, according RBI data). He also says businesses are forced to make capital investments when capacity utilisation touches 85% and expects that time to come by the end of this year.


Domino EffectTo make matters worse, the banking and financial sector saw a series of debacles in 2018. It began with the Letter of Credit scam at Punjab National Bank involving jeweller Nirav Modi followed by a default on debt payments by IL&FS, an infrastructure sector-focused non-banking financial company (NBFC), and ending with a housing finance meltdown towards. This year, Chanda Kochhar was sacked as CEO of ICICI Bank over allegations of misdemeanour.

The IL&FS default brought the country’s entire shadowbanking sector to its knees after other NBFCs faced a bank credit squeeze. As a result, short-term lending by NBFCs and mutual funds to companies whose promoters pledged their shares as security against borrowing came under the scanner. The selling of pledged shares by lenders led to a crash in scrip prices of Zee Entertainment Enterprises Ltd (ZEEL) as well as companies of the Reliance Anil Dhirubhai Ambani Group. To induce stability and bring back confidence in the management Subhash Chandra, promoter of ZEEL, and the Wadhawans, promoters of Dewan Housing Finance Corporation, promised to induct strategic equity partners in their companies. There are few business groups in the country today that are ready to invest, except probably Gautam Adani-led Adani Enterprises, Sajjan Jindal-led JSW Steel and Mukesh Ambani-led Reliance Industries.


 Kolkata-based SREI Group, promoted by brothers Hemant and Sunil Kanoria, had to bear the brunt of the IL&FS crisis. The scrip of SREI Infrastructure tanked in the aftermath of the crisis and the group had to abandon its plan to list its equipment finance subsidiary.

“There is no long-term funding available for infrastructure projects or for other greenfield projects. Going forward, banks will not be in a position to indulge in term-lending,” SREI vice-chairman Sunil Kanoria told ET Magazine.

The tried-and-tested model of banks, flush with saving and current account deposits, funding large infrastructure or capacity addition by companies, has outlived its utility. There is no way to go back. Kanoria says that a new form of funding led by institutions, especially the ones in development finance, has to be developed.

It is a view echoed by Sandeep Upadhyay, MD of Centrum Infrastructure Advisory, an investment banking firm. He feels much of India’s infrastructure funding requirement will have to be catered by the likes of foreign sovereign and pension funds since they are better aligned to the sector’s riskreturn profile. “While many of these long term investment funds are evaluating buying out operational assets in India, there is limited interest to invest in greenfield projects. I guess it may take another year or two for these pension funds to cultivate interest in greenfield opportunities.”

Easy availability of credit in the last decade had led to a model where infrastructure projects were running on 75-80% debt funding. Much of the equity too was also debt money borrowed by the parent entity and infused into projects as equity, effectively increasing the debt component.

IL&FS itself was ticked off recently by accounting firm Grant Thornton that was asked to look into the lender’s books. The problem with highly leveraged financing is that there is little buffer left for miscalculations, and this is what afflicted India’s infrastructure and power sector leading to series of bankruptcies.


Not Full SteamSo if we ask: How is the mood inside India Inc and how many are raring to go and take up new opportunities, there are unlikely to be any straightforward answers.

Mining is a key area that brings in heavy investments. In an earlier interview to ET, Aditya Birla Group chairman Kumar Mangalam Birla had said that while allocation of natural resources had become more transparent, his group preferred a state-by-state approach as different states acted differently and their risk profiles varied.

A senior banker, who spoke to ET Magazine on condition of anonymity, agrees about the investment cycle restarting only in the third quarter of 2019-20 after a new government is in place. He said there is a fear psychosis, but the IBC, although imperfect, has brought in a sigh of relief.

There are structural issues too that companies needs to sort out amid the Income Tax department and the Enforcement Directorate coming down hard on corporate irregularities. Recognising this problem, the Confederation of Indian Industry (CII) has been asking its members to sign a model code of conduct and business ethics document.




“Many actions of the government have helped. The Mauritius route of bringing in your own money has been virtually plugged. It has become tougher to do shady deals,” says Piruz Khambatta, chairman of Rasna and chairman of CII’s Western Regional Council. Khambatta is someone looking ahead at the election months. Summer is near, and for soft drink maker Rasna, it is an important season.

But every industrialist ET Magazine spoke to prefers to wait out the elections, and hopes for a “stable government” before taking any major decision.

BK Goenka, chairman of Welspun Group and president of Associated Chambers of Commerce and Industry of India, feels bold decisions need time to settle down and businesses too need time to adjust to a new paradigm that excludes overleveraging. “If we get a stable government, the next five years can be golden years.”

Mumbai: The Essel Group has put its mutual fund business on the block in its drive to monetise nonmedia businesses amid concerns over debt repayment, said three persons with direct knowledge of the development.

Srei Mutual Fund Asset Management, Avendus Capital and Lodha Ventures Holdings are currently in the race to acquire Essel Mutual Fund, which has Assets Under Management (AUM) worth about Rs 1,428 crore, in a deal estimated to be valued at around Rs 100 crore.

“The deal talks have reached the final stages and are expected to be concluded over the next few weeks,” said one of the persons mentioned above.

ET’s separate email queries to Lodha Ventures and Avendus Capital remained unanswered till the time of going to press. Spokespersons for Essel Group and Srei Mutual Fund Asset Management declined to comment on the story.

In 2016, Essel Finance Wealth Zone Private Ltd (EFWZ), a whollyowned subsidiary of Essel Finance Management LLP, had acquired the entire shareholding of Essel Finance AMC, formerly Peerless Funds Management Company, and Essel MF Trustee Limited formerly Peerless Trust Management Company.

At the group level, Essel has total debt of Rs 17,174 crore and out of this, Rs 11,466 crore is the infra-related debt. This infra-related debt covers three major verticals -- power transmission, solar and roads (toll and annuity).

On January 31, ET had reported that from non-media business, the company plans to monetise about Rs 20,000 crore over the next 6 months by selling its infrastructure assets.

Promoters of Essel Group are already in talks with multiple companies, including Sony Pictures and Comcast, to sell up to 50% of their holding in Zee Entertainment Enterprises. The Subhash Chandra-promoted group has also started working on a plan to monetise its non-media businesses in order to pare debt.

Apart from repaying its infrastructure-related debt, the company is planning to use the funds raised through asset monetisation to reduce the pledged portion of the promoter shares in Zee Entertainment Enterprises. The promoters had pledged their 59% stake in Zee Entertainment to raise money that served as equity funding for the group’s infrastructurerelated businesses.



Last week, in a separate development, Delta Corp announced entering into an agreement to invest $10 million in Jalesh Cruises Mauritius Ltd, an Essel Group company. This transaction is expected to be completed in one or more tranches, on or before June 30.

According to the regulatory filing by Delta Corp, the investment to be made through its subsidiary Gaussian Software will entitle Gaussian Software to subscribe to 10 million equity shares of the Essel Group’s cruise line business Jalesh. This will, in turn, enable the company to hold 25 per cent stake in the Mauritius company.

Jalesh, promoted by Amit Goenka, is planning to acquire cruise ships and operate cruise services to various destinations in India and the Middle East. As part of the arrangement, Delta Corp has acquired the right to be a preferred partner to manage and operate casinos and gaming centres in the cruise liners that will be operated by Jalesh.

NEW DELHI: Nifty futures on the Singapore Exchange were trading 0.50 point, or 0.001 per cent, higher at 11,384, indicating a flat start for the Nifty50. Here are a few stocks which may buzz the most in today's trade: 


Zee Entertainment: According to a media report, promoters may sell 20 per cent stake in Zee to Sony for Rs 13,000 crore. The amount will be used to repay debt. 


Lupin: USFDA has classified the inspection conducted at the company's Mandideep (Unit 1) facility in December as 'Official Action Indicated' (OAI). The facility could be subject to regulatory or administrative action. 


Mindtree, L&T Infotech: L&T Infotech (LTI) is likely to sign a deal with Café Coffee Day founder VG Siddhartha and his associates in the next four days to buy their 21 per cent stake in Mindtree, people briefed on the matter said.


DHFL: Private equity firms Kedaara Capital and Warburg Pincus have emerged as the highest bidders for Avanse Financial Services, an educational services financier owned by the holding company of DHFL. Meanwhile, NHB has concluded its inspection of books for DHFL's alleged misappropriation of loans.


PNB: Punjab National Bank has put its stake in CRIF High Mark, a credit information company that tracks individual and corporate payment history, on sale as it looks to sell all non-core investments and offset the delay in monetising its stake in life insurance business.


Wipro: Azim Premji said all earnings from 34 per cent shares worth about Rs 52,750 crore ($7.5 billion) — would be transferred to the endowment that supports the Azim Premji Foundation. With this, Premji has committed earnings from 67 per cent of Wipro’s shares to his charitable foundation. 


Jet Airways: Three airline, which is in the midst of restructuring its operations, has become a standard account for most of the lenders as it has begun meeting payment in the past two months, said two people familiar with the matter.


PFC, REC: International lenders have given their go-ahead to Power Finance Corp's nearly Rs 14,000-crore proposal to buy out REC Ltd for a high fee, clearing the final hurdle for the deal which is crucial for the government to meet its disinvestment target.

HCL Technologies: The IT major will acquire Strong-Bridge Envision in a bid to enhance Digital Transformation Consulting capabilities. 


Reliance Industries: A US subsidiary of RIL has stopped all business with Petróleos de Venezuela (PDVSA), the state-owned oil company of Venezuela, to comply with US sanctions on the Latin American country, an RIL spokesperson said.


Larsen & Toubro: The company's image with customers hinges on a transparent probe into its alleged involvement in the Cognizant bribery case, as India’s biggest engineering group expands its business to cement its credentials as a global technology leader.

• Kotak Securities has maintained its add rating on Mahindra CIE with an unchanged fair value of Rs 265, valuing the company at 15 times December 2020 estimated EPS. The company expects doubledigit growth in revenues over the next two years due to strong growth in the exports business.

Ad rates for political advertising have shot up, doubling in some instances, from those paid by other advertisers as India gets ready to vote in a seven-phase general election that starts on April 11. Leading media buying companies and broadcasters said the 2019 election campaign will set a new record for political ad spending, some pegging it at Rs 4,000 crore, up 40% from the 2014 election. The last day of voting is May 19 with counting scheduled for May 23.

“Pre-election ad rates have increased about 100% compared with other corporate advertisers’ rates,” said Shashi Sinha, chief executive of IPG Mediabrands, which represents Coca-Cola and Amazon among others. “While the BJP and Congress are obviously taking the leading in advertising, regional parties have emerged as heavy spenders too. The spends on election advertising could touch Rs 4,000 crore, with the number of parties and contenders having shot up significantly over the previous election season.”



TV ad rates, especially those of news channels, go up at election time, said Ashish Sehgal, chief growth officer, ad revenue, Zee Entertainment Enterprises (ZEE). “The viewership of the news genre goes up almost 18-20% during elections and its mainly male viewership,” he said. “A lot of clients who target male viewers also shift to the news genre. During this period, we will see almost 25-30% increase in ad rates and in some cases may be up to 40%.”

Sehgal said there would be an increase in overall rates and political parties will also have to pay those. He didn’t say if political parties would be charged a premium. ZEE has also launched an election package for sponsors at a premium of over 30%.

On polling, counting and government formation days, viewership surges, Sehgal said. “These are the days when rates also go up to as much as Rs 2 lakh per 10 seconds. It’s like T20, airing all day on a news channel.”

Broadcasters will seek to maximise the opportunity for the biggest news event of the year, said a top ad sales executive at a large TV network. “Similar to the festival season, elections are also big for advertising, which comes every five years,” he said. “Political parties that want to reach mass audiences have to pay up. As they will be advertising for just a month or two, we are charging 20-30% more, compared to our regular clients, who advertise with us for the entire year.” Experts said advertisers across genres will need to cut through increased clutter over next 30-45 days to connect with viewers. “Political parties evidently have very deep pockets,” said Vani Gupta, former marketing director, PepsiCo, and cofounder of Benddit, a platform that provides turnkey sales and marketing solutions. “The challenge is before business houses who are jostling for visibility in the same media. This is when advertisers must deliberately pick new age media to get the attention of their consumers and circumnavigate the conventional roadblocks.”

According to a directive by the Indian Broadcasting Foundation (IBF) grouping, political parties have to pay in advance for ads. “They have to pay a premium, plus in advance, which is a major advantage for broadcasters,” the executive said.

As per tracking firm Centre for Media Studies, the election exercise as a whole will cost a record Rs 50,000 crore ($7 billion) as more than 8,000 candidates contest 543 seats.

MUMBAI: It’s not just telecom, but also TV distribution space where Sunil Bharti Mittal has decided to give a tough fight to Mukesh Ambani’s Reliance Jio.

As Ambani’ Jio has taken control of the two largest cable operators – Hathway Cable & Datacom and DEN Networks — Mittal has initiated talks with Dish TV, to merge his DTH business, housed under Airtel Digital TV, said two people with direct knowledge of the development.

“The talks are at exploratory stage,” said one of the persons. “Idea is to consolidate operations and give a strong fight to Reliance Jio. Together, Airtel Digital TV and Dish TV will be a giant.” If Mittal succeeds, the combined entity will be the world’s largest TV distribution company with over 38 million subscribers and 61% DTH market share in India.

Replying to an ET query, an Airtel spokesperson said, “As a policy, we do not comment on market speculation.”

A Dish TV spokesperson also said that the company “does not comment on market speculations.”




It was in March last year when Dish TV completed merger of Videocon d2h with itself, kick-starting the consolidation in the Indian DTH space, the only market with six (five pay and one free) DTH players.

Airtel, in the past, had tried to sell its DTH business to Tata Sky, but the two parties couldn’t reach an agreement. Later, in December 2017, Airtel sold 20% stake in Bharti Telemedia, the holding company of Airtel Digital TV, to private equity firm Warburg Pincus for $350 million (Rs 2,258 crore), valuing the DTH business at Rs 11,300 crore.

Dish TV’s market cap as of March 15 was at Rs 7,263.75 crore, down from the estimated combined valuation of Rs 17,000 crore at the time of merger last year. Tata Sky’s valuation is estimated between Rs 11,000-12,000 crore.

As per Trai report on DTH market, as of September 2018, Dish TV (combined with Videocon d2h) leads with a 37% market share, followed by Tata Sky (27%) and Airtel Digital TV (24%). As of quarter ended December 31st, 2018, Dish TV had 23.6 million subscribers and it reported operating revenue of Rs 1,517.4 crore, and EBIDTA of Rs 517.6 crore. Dish TV’s average revenue per user was at Rs 200.

Promoters own 60.8% stake in the company, while pledged holdings are worth Rs 3,625 crore.

Airtel Digital TV, meanwhile, had 15 million subscribers as of Q3, FY19. Its revenue from the DTH business was at Rs 1,033 crore, while EBITDA and margins were at Rs 382.6 crore and 37%, respectively, during the quarter.

Airtel Digital TV’s ARPU was higher at Rs 231. Interestingly, earlier this month, Jawahar Goel, CMD at Dish TV, and part of the Essel Group promoter family, was given additional responsibility as editor-in-chief of Zee Media Corp, which houses news channels of the Subhash Chandra-promoted ZEE Group.

Subhash Chandra, Goel’s brother and chairman of Essel Group, is already in talks to sell up to half of promoters’ stake in Zee Entertainment Enterprises.

NEW DELHI: Nifty futures on the Singapore Exchange were trading 18 points, or 0.16 per cent, higher at 11,529.50, indicating a positive start for the Nifty50. Here are a few stocks, which may buzz the most in today's trade:


L&T, Mindtree: L&T has entered into a deal to buy Cafe Coffee Day owner V G Siddhartha's 20.32 per cent stake in Mindtree and has also placed an order with brokers to pick up another 15 per cent of the company shares from the open market. Subsequent to these deals, L&T would make an open offer to buy additional 31 per cent stake through an open offer.


Jet Airways: Etihad Airways is believed to have formally conveyed to Jet Airways’ top lender State Bank of India that it won’t make any further investment in the airline.


RCom: Nearly 15 months after Anil Ambani agreed to sell assets of Reliance Communications to a telecom firm run by elder brother Mukesh, the two groups Monday called off the deal citing delays in approval from the government and lenders.


Real estate stocks: The GST Council in its 34th meeting to be held on Tuesday is expected to take up various issues, including the implementation of lower GST rates for the real estate sector.


Hotel Leela Venture: The company announced sale of four hotels, including one in the national capital, and a property to Canadian investment fund Brookfield Asset Management for Rs 3,950 crore.


Tata Motors: UK arm Jaguar Land Rover (JLR) is recalling over 44,000 units in the UK to rectify emission issues in models manufactured between 2016-19.


Adani Ports and Special Economic Zone (APSEZ): The company said its board has given nod for buyback of non-convertible debentures (NCDs) worth Rs 1,400 crore.


Tata Chemicals: The company has signed a non- exclusive agreement with the Indian Space Research Organisation for the latter's lithium-ion cell technology.


ZEEL, Voda Idea: Vodafone Idea and Zee Entertainment Enterprises (ZEEL) have entered into a tie-up on the latter’s over-the-top (OTT) platform ZEE5, in a bid to raise content play to take on rivals Reliance Jio and Bharti Airtel.


Eclerx Services: Retail investors could make 12-30 per cent in Eclerx Services over the next three months through arbitrage after the technology process management company last week announced a buyback of its shares.


IPO WATCH
The initial public offering (IPO) by Embassy Office Parks REIT got subscribed 20 per cent on the first day of the offer on Monday. The public offer received bids for 1,39,30,400 shares till 5 pm as against the total issue size of 7,12,56,400 shares offered by the company.


Board meetings



Analyst calls

• Kotak Securities has recommended to buy Engineers India with a target price of Rs 153 as they believe EIL stock is trading at cheap valuation at PER 14x FY 2020 core earnings. EIL management reiterated positive outlook on the domestic order inflows driven by brownfield expansion of refineries, set up & integration of petrochemical plants with existing refineries and greenfield refinery expansion- including Maharashtra Refinery. 

 • Morgan Stanley has upgraded the rating of Kotak Mahindra Bank to overweight and raised the target price to ₹1,600 from Rs 1,365. The key factors, according to Morgan Stanley for the upgrade includes return of pricing power at private banks, partly helped by higher rates in wholesale markets and the funding crisis at NBFCs, improving credit risk situation in the corporate/SME segment. 

 • Reliance Securities has maintained its buy recommendation on ACC with a marginally revised target price of Rs 1,720. The brokerage continues to maintain their positive view on ACC owing to its deep penetration in the rural markets and consistent focus on premium products. 

• Geojit has downgraded the rating of Cadila Healthcare to hold with a revised target price of ₹358 based on 18x FY21E EPS. Highly leveraged balance sheet post Heinz India acquisition, which was funded largely through debt, remain a near term concern. 

• ICICI Securities has downgraded the ratings of Sterlite Technologies to hold and cut the target price to ₹230 per share citing pricing pressure. Some rub-off of steep correction in fibre optic cable prices in China and in other geographies may result in some downward revision of prices when they come to renegotiation, said the brokerage.

NEW DELHI: Vodafone Idea Ltd (VIL) and Zee Entertainment Enterprises Ltd (ZEEL) have entered into a tie up for the latter's over-the-top (OTT) platform ZEE5, in a bid to raise content play to take on rivals Reliance Jio and Bharti Airtel. Under the partnership, the content portfolio of ZEE5 will be available to Vodafone Idea customers on Vodafone Play as well as Idea movies and TV app, the Mumbai-based telco said in a statement Monday. 

The telecom market leader said its customers of Vodafone Idea can now access the entire content catalogue of ZEE5 via multiple devices. The content of ZEE5 can be accessed through Vodafone Play or Idea movies and TV app. The ZEE5 content is available across 12 languages; English, Hindi, Bengali, Malayalam, Tamil, Telugu, Kannada, Marathi, Oriya, Bhojpuri, Gujarati and Punjabi.

"Our customers are constantly seeking rich and diverse content options and we aim to provide enriched entertainment by offering high-quality content on Vodafone Play and Idea movies and TV," Avneesh Khosla, operations director - marketing, Vodafone Idea, said in the statement.

Sun TV Network (down 2.94 per cent) , PVR (down 1.92 per cent) , TV Today Network (down 1.22 per cent) and Eros International Media (down 1.11 per cent) too were trading with lower. 

The Nifty Media index was trading 2.65 per cent down at 2345.95 around 02:11 pm. 

Benchmark NSE Nifty50 index was down 120.25 points at 11,336.65 while the BSE Sensex was down 419.49 points at 37,745.12. 

Among the 50 stocks in the Nifty index, 11 were trading in the green, while 39 were in the red. 

Shares of BHEL, YES Bank, SAIL, Indian Oil Corp, NTPC, SBI, ONGC, Bank of Baroda, Tata Motors, Ashok Leyland, ICICI Bank, BEL, Zee Ent. and RIL were among the most traded shares on the NSE.

With regards to Nifty, there will always be these technical levels where you could see some amount of correction happening in the stocks
  
  
  , said Abhimanyu Sofat, VP- Research, IIFL, in an interview with ETNOW. Edited excerpts:


While the global concerns remain, markets seem to have stabilised somewhat but back home, we have seen markets tapering off in last three sessions. Would the markets pick up steam once again?
Whatever has happened globally, net-net it is a positive for India. The inversion of the 10-year bond yield curve in the US, is a repeat of a similar situation in December. After that, we saw a rally happening in India after a period of time. So, I do not think concerns about global recession are too worrying for India per se. 

The only thing that the market has already factored in is what will happen in May in terms of elections. Any development that is drastically different from market expectations could spook the market at this particular juncture. 

Globally, FIIs have been pumping in close to around Rs 38,000-crore odd this year. It clearly shows that the momentum in terms of inflows will continue going forward for FIIs for the coming weeks, if not months. That is likely to sustain the market going forward. In terms of flows on the domestic side also, the market improves. The momentum in terms of SIPs, which had come down a bit over the last couple of months, should also come back to the market. We do not think anything has changed structurally in the last couple of days that will change the overall momentum in terms of the broader market.

With regards to Nifty, there will always be these technical levels where you could see some amount of correction happening in the stocks.


Would you be a buyer in Jet Airways? 
As of now, the answer to your question would be no because the challenge which is there in terms of how to run an airline efficiently still has not been answered by Jet. Except for Interglobe Aviation and to some extent Spice Jet, we have not seen any other airline which has been able to run a very low-cost operation in India. Those structural issues remain and we still do not know who will be the new management. As many questions are still left unanswered, I do not think it is a buy. From a momentum perspective, the stock may go up a bit because of the deal which has happened since some people might have contemplated that Jet would cease to exist. From that perspective, there could be a short-term rally but from a structural long-term perspective, I do not think Jet is a good buy right now, It will be very hard for the airline over next couple of months to show reasonably good profit which can lead to good investors coming and buying Jet Airways.


Is it the time for a relook at DLF?
DLF should do well going forward, considering that on both fronts, we believe their rental portfolio is likely to do pretty well going forward. Going forward with this kind of fundraise which they have done, what companies have been talking about in terms of reducing their debt level significantly and hopefully becoming a zero-debt company, looks quite possible going forward. 

The other thing is there is a complete change in terms of how the real estate market is behaving in India. Earlier you had the prelaunch and then over a period of seven-eight years, builders were trying to postpone giving delivery to take advantage of the appreciation happening. Now with GST, RERA and demonetisation, it is in the interest of the builders to give the property to buyers as soon as possible. DLF is announcing that for the new projects they will sell ready-to- move-in flats and that clearly shows that they will have a decent amount of advantage over other companies in NCR. We are quite positive on DLF going forward.


Have you taken a relook at any of these names -- PFC, REC, NTPC?
We find NTPC quite attractive, considering that the margin of safety is quite decent in the stock and from a dividend yield perspective also it looks quite good to us. Going forward, with the changes which have been announced over last couple of weeks, we expect that the some of the challenges that the power sector may be mitigated. Some of the power plants were not getting adequate fuel as they had some issues with regards to financing. Those kind of issues would get sorted out and as a result, for a person who has a defensive kind of a mindset but wants to be in equities, NTPC looks quite a decent stock to own.

ET Now: Considering midcaps have seen a fair amount of revival as well in this March rally, what within midcaps are you liking and if the markets were to decline, what would be on your buy list?

Abhimanyu Sofat: We like stories like Ipca Labs because we believe that the growth rate will be very good for next two years with a CAGR of close of 23%. The growth in the domestic market would be 1.5x of the industry growth. Second, in international market, a lot of the challenges that they are facing with USFDA would get resolved over next three-four quarters. For that reason, we see a pickup in demand from there as well. This is one of the stocks that we really like. 

The other one that we can look at is a Capcite India because there is a big improvement in demand coming in terms of setting up of a new factories all across India. The entire private sector consumption is picking up and as a result of that, we see private infra capex improving. Capacite valuations also are quite cheap at this particular stage. These are the kind of stocks that right now we are quite bullish on.


In media space, there has been a lot of interest in Zee Entertainment with the strategic stake sale likely to culminate soon. How are you looking at Dish TV and the entire Essel Group of stocks? 
In terms of business, Zee business continues to remain quite robust in terms of ad revenue growth. Subscription growth numbers were quite good for last quarter. Obviously after strategic sale, what kind of synergies that bring in will be key trigger for the stock. 

If one right now is holding the stock, one should continue to hold the stock because they have clearly been gaining market share in the market over some of the other players like Sony. It is a good stock to own within the media space. Our preference within the sector would be a Zee as well as something like a Sun TV, where there is likely to be decent growth going forward.

Mumbai: Entities belongs to Subhash Chandra of Essel Group have sold 76.35 lakh shares worth Rs 333 crore in Zee Entertainment in the open market between February 13, 2019 and March 29, 2019. According to multiple regulatory filings, promoter group entity Cyquator Media Services has sold 53.18 lakh shares of Zee, while Essel Corporate LLP sold 23.17 lakh shares in the entertainment company. Essel Groups promoters have been selling shares of its group companies since its crises started earlier this year. 

Essel group stocks crashed up to 33 per cent on January 25, 2019 following which its chairman Subhash Chandra said his company is in a financial mess and has blamed the same for the aggressive bets on infra plays, which has gone out of control since the IL&FS crisis and also the acquisition of Videocon’s D2H business. He also blamed some negative forces for sabotaging his efforts to raise money through a strategic sale in the flagship company Zee Entertainment Enterprises.

NEW DELHI: Nifty futures on the Singapore Exchange were trading 10.50 points, or 0.09 per cent, higher at 11,744.50, indicating a positive start for the Nifty50. Here are a few stocks which may buzz the most in today's trade: 


Zee Entertainment: Entities that belongs to Subhash Chandra of Essel Group have sold 76.35 lakh shares worth ₹333 crore in Zee Entertainment in the open market between February 13, 2019 and March 29, 2019.


Godrej Properties: Realty firm Godrej Properties said it sold 2,900 flats for over Rs 2,100 crore during the fourth quarter of last fiscal.In a statement, the Mumbai-based developer said it has achieved its highest ever bookings numbers in Q4 FY19. 


Cipla: Domestic pharma major Cipla said it has signed a binding agreement with Pulmatrix Inc for co-development and licensing opportunity for a new drug under development for an upfront consideration of $22 million.


Eicher Motors: The company announced Rs 700 crore capital expenditure plan for Royal Enfield in the current financial year.The company has appointed Vinod K Dasari as the chief executive officer of its Royal Enfield unit.


Coal India: The company clocked a 4.8 per cent growth in sales to 608 million tonnes (mt) while production registered a 7 per cent growth to 607 mt during 2018-19. 


HAL: State owned Hindustan Aeronautics has recorded turnover of over Rs 19,400 crore for the 2018-19 financial year, ending March 31 against Rs 18,284 crore in the previous year.


Usha Martin: Basant Kumar Jhawar, former chairman and a founding promoter of Usha Martin, who was ousted from the board at the EGM last week, Monday vouched to fight back for his rights.


Jet Airways: Lenders to Jet Airways have zeroed in on Ernst & Young (EY) as the new auditor for the troubled airlines. The interim management committee, which is being formed, will formally appoint EY, people familiar with the matter said. EY won the race in which Deloitte was a close contender.


Uttam Value Steels: The National Company Law Tribunal (NCLT) on Monday allowed an extension of about 20 days for the resolution of the stressed assets of Uttam Galva companies —Uttam Value Steels and Uttam Galva Metallics.


Maruti Suzuki: The country's largest carmaker Maruti Suzuki India (MSI) Monday said it has increased vehicle prices by up to Rs 689 across models on account of mandatory high security registration plates from April 1.


Embassy Office Parks REIT: India’s first share sale in a property collection under one operator became the country’s second-most valuable real estate company on its stock-market debut, highlighting the potential of an investment product that already finds favour with the uberrich in New York, Singapore or London.


Adani Enterprises: Adani Enterprises said said it has incorporated a joint venture firm with Sainik Mining and Allied Services Company for carrying out mining activities in Chhattishagarh.


Tata Motors: Tata Motors' local sales dropped 12 per cent in March to 17,810 units. For the fiscal year, however, the numbers were up 12% at 2,10,143.


Mahindra & Mahindra: For the month of March, the company sold 62,952 units, a marginal growth over March 2018. 


Board meetings
 Analyst calls
• Edelweiss has maintained its buy recommendation on SRF with a target price of ₹2,315 as pick up in specialty chemical business was a strong earnings kicker for the company. In the long run, the company’s leadership in refrigerant gas and significant capital expenditure in specialty chemicals will drive return ratios and other segments like technical textiles and packaging film to continue to generate strong cash flows, said the brokerage. 

• Emkay has initiated coverage on Capacite Infraprojects with a buy rating and set a target price of ₹288 citing strong growth path with attractive valuation. Besides government reforms such as real estate regulatory authority, the company is well-positioned to gain traction driven by impressive execution track with stable margins, lean balance sheet with healthy return ratios, strong management pedigree and asset-light business model said the brokerage. 

• Elara Capital has maintained its buy rating on TCS with a target price of ₹2,400 as the 19.8% PE premium assigned for TCS based on consensus estimates is inadequate. The brokerage expects the margin gap to widen further over FY20 as it expect TCS to improve operating profit margin by 180 bps year-onyear to 28.8%, even as Infosys sees operating profit margin erode by 100 bps year-on-year to 24.2%, said the brokerage. 

• Axis Securities has initiated coverage on Chalet Hotels with a buy rating and set a target price of ₹410. Chalet stems from its unique positioning and efficient asset management strategy such as the industry is coming out of a 10-year lull and we find it prudent to back asset owners in an upcycle – superior operating profit case in point, said the brokerage. 

• Edelweiss has maintained its buy rating on DLF with a target price of ₹237. DLF has successfully completed a qualified institutional placement of ₹3,170 crore involving an issuance of 173 mn shares at ₹183.4 apiece. This paves the way for the balance fund infusion of ₹2,250 crore by promoters as well as conversion of debentures/warrants worth the entire ₹11,250 crore into equity shares, said the brokerage.

NEW DELHI: The Nifty Financial Services index was up with its components trading higher in Tuesday's afternoon session.

Shares of Bajaj Holdings & Investment (up 2.80 per cent), ICICI Prudential Life Insurance Company (up 1.45 per cent), Power Finance Corporation (up 1.42 per cent) and State Bank of India (up 1.38 per cent) were trading with gains.

Max Financial Services (up 1.13 per cent), Bajaj Finserv (up 0.92 per cent), Bajaj Finance (up 0.88 per cent) and Axis Bank (up 0.77 per cent) too were trading with gains. 

The Nifty Financial Services index was trading 0.13 per cent up at 12,515.85 around 12:39 pm. 

Benchmark NSE Nifty50 index was up 39.55 points at 11,708.70 while the BSE Sensex was up 154.35 points at 39,026.22.

Among the 50 stocks in the Nifty index, 29 were trading in the green, while 21 were in the red. 

Shares of Tata Motors, Vodafone Idea, BEL, Bank of Baroda, SBI, YES Bank, SAIL, DLF, Ashok Leyland, Bharti Airtel, BHEL, ICICI Bank, Zee Entertainment, Indian Oil Corp, NTPC, ONGC, PowerGrid, Tata Motors, Vedanta and RIL were among the most traded shares on the NSE.

NEW DELHI: Shares of most sugar producing companies fell in Tuesday's afternoon session. 

Indian Sucrose (down 4.88 per cent), Dwarikesh Sugar Industries (down 4.57 per cent), Triveni Engineering & Industries (down 4.30 per cent), Piccadily Agro Industries (down 3.76 per cent), Dalmia Bharat Sugar & Industries (down 3.60 per cent) and Piccadily Sugar & Allied Inds (down 3.10 per cent) declined up to 5 per cent. 

Uttam Sugar Mills (down 2.51 per cent), Mawana Sugars (down 2.32 per cent), Dhampure Specialty Sugars (down 2.11 per cent), Dhampur Sugar Mills (down 2.08 per cent), Avadhsugar (down 1.97 per cent), Balrampur Chini Mills (down 1.86 per cent), Rajshree Sugars & Chemicals (down 1.77 per cent), BAJAJHIND (down 1.54 per cent), Thiru Arooran Sugars (down 1.45 per cent), Magadhsugar (down 1.34 per cent) and Dharani Sugars & Chemicals (down 1.32 per cent) also declined significantly.

Meanwhile, shares of Sir Shadi Lal Enterprises (up 4.70 per cent), Rana Sugars (up 2.82 per cent), Simbhaoli Sugars (up 1.99 per cent), Parvati (up 1.39 per cent), Ponni Sugars (Erode) (up 1.14 per cent) and Ugar Sugar Works (up 0.31 per cent) climbed in Tuesday's session. 

The NSE Nifty50 index was trading 4.15 points down at 11,665 while the 30share BSE Sensex was up 33.91 points at 38,905.78 at around the same time. 

Tata Motors (up 5.95 per cent), Bharti Airtel (up 4.80 per cent), Eicher Motors (up 2.64 per cent) and GAIL (India) (up 2.20 per cent) were among the top gainers in the Nifty pack. 

On the other hand, Zee Entertainment Enterprises (down 4.44 per cent), Bharat Petroleum Corporation (down 3.04 per cent), Hindustan Petroleum Corporation (down 2.48 per cent) and Bajaj Auto (down 2.22 per cent) were trading in the red.

NEW DELHI: IT shares were trading higher in Tuesday's morning session.

Shares of NIIT Technologies (up 1.30 per cent), Tata Elxsi (up 1.17 per cent), Oracle Financial Services Software (up 0.73 per cent) and Tata Consultancy Services (up 0.66 per cent) were the top gainers in the index.

Mindtree (up 0.61 per cent), Infosys (up 0.54 per cent) and Tech Mahindra (up 0.29 per cent) were trading with gains. 

The Nifty IT index was trading 0.41 per cent up at 15,905.95 around 10:10 am. 

Benchmark NSE Nifty50 index was up 3.60 points at 11,672.75 while the BSE Sensex was up 29.56 points at 38,901.43. 

Among the 50 stocks in the Nifty index, 24 were trading in the green, while 24 were in the red. 

Shares of Tata Motors, BEL, Bank of Baroda, SBI, YES Bank, Zee Entertainment, Ashok Leyland, SAIL and DLF were among the most traded shares on the NSE.

NEW DELHI: Metal shares were trading in the positive zone in Tuesday's morning session.

Shares of NMDC (up 2.04 per cent), Steel Authority of India (SAIL) (up 1.73 per cent), MOIL (up 1.50 per cent) and Jindal Steel & Power (up 1.29 per cent) were the top performers in the index.

Vedanta (up 0.50 per cent), Hindalco Industries (up 0.37 per cent), Coal India (up 0.30 per cent) and APL Apollo Tubes (up 0.13 per cent) too were trading in the green. 

The Nifty Metal index was trading 0.11 per cent up at 3105.75 around 11:00 am. 

Benchmark NSE Nifty50 index was up 4.80 points at 11,673.95 while the BSE Sensex was up 34.64 points at 38,906.51.

Among the 50 stocks in the Nifty index, 28 were trading in the green, while 22 were in the red. 

Shares of Vodafone Idea, Tata Motors, BEL, Bank of Baroda, SBI, Ashok Leyland, SAIL, YES Bank, BHEL, Zee Entertainment, DLF, Bharti Airtel, ONGC, ICICI Bank and Indian Oil Corp were among the most traded shares on the NSE.

NEW DELHI: Shares of Zee Entertainment Enterprises were swinging between gains and losses after it cracked over 4 per cent in early trade on Tuesday.

On Monday, the company said in a BSE filing that entities belonging to Subhash Chandra of Essel Group sold 76.35 lakh shares worth Rs 333 crore in Zee Entertainment in the open market between February 13, 2019, and March 29, 2019.

According to multiple regulatory filings, promoter group entity Cyquator Media Services has sold 53.18 lakh shares of Zee, while Essel Corporate LLP sold 23.17 lakh shares in the entertainment company. 

The company in a note to ETMarkets.com clarified that none of the lenders with whom the agreement has been reached have sold any shares. "The understanding with the lenders stays firm and constant and the Group is thankful to them (lenders) for their support and trust," the statement read.

Essel Groups promoters have been selling shares of its group companies since its crises started earlier this year. 

The shares of the company closed at Rs 418.10 apiece down 2.98 per cent on BSE.

NEW DELHI: Most agri sector stocks were trading with losses in Wednesday's session after private weather forecasting agency Skymet said that monsoon rains in India are expected to be below normal this year dampening prospects of higher farm and economic growth. 

According to Skymet Weather, monsoon in 2019 was likely to be ‘below normal’ to the tune of 93 per cent of the long period average (LPA) of 887 mm for the fourthmonth period from June to September. 

Companies such as Jain Irrigation, Escorts, PI Industries pared gains and were trading down up to 3 per cent in the afternoon trade. Skymet sees below normal monsoon due to climate change and carbon emissions. 

AgriTech (India) (down 4.42 per cent), Proseed India (down 4.35 per cent), Indo Us (down 3.32 per cent), Jain Irrigation Systems (down 3.11 per cent), Avanti Feeds (down 2.71 per cent), Camson Bio Technologies (down 2.26 per cent) and Chamanlal Setia Exports (down 2.14 per cent) declined up to 5 per cent. 

Simran Farms (down 1.84 per cent), Kohinoor Foods (down 1.77 per cent) and KRBL (down 1.60 per cent) also declined significantly. 

Meanwhile, shares of Ocean Agro (India) (up 4.90 per cent), MISHTANN (up 1.97 per cent), Trescon (up 1.70 per cent), Freshtrop Fruits (up 1.21 per cent) and Kaveri Seed Company (up 0.89 per cent) were trading with gains. 

The NSE Nifty50 index was trading 5.70 points down at 11,707.50 while the 30share BSE Sensex was up 27.29 points at 39,083.94 at around 02:39 pm. 

Indiabulls Housing Finance (up 3.95 per cent), Maruti Suzuki India (up 2.21 per cent), Bajaj Finserv (up 1.80 per cent), JSW Steel (up 1.62 per cent), HCL Technologies (up 1.55 per cent) and Tata Steel (up 1.35 per cent) were among the top gainers in the Nifty pack. 

On the other hand, Hindustan Petroleum Corporation (down 4.09 per cent), Bharat Petroleum Corporation (down 4.06 per cent), Indian Oil Corporation (down 2.12 per cent) and Zee Entertainment Enterprises (down 2.03 per cent) were trading in the red.

NEW DELHI: Media shares were trading in the negative zone in Wednesday's afternoon session.

Shares of Inox Leisure (down 2.99 per cent) , Network 18 Media & Investments (down 2.21 per cent) , Hathway Cable & Datacom (down 2.17 per cent) and Dish TV India (down 2.02 per cent) were trading with losses.

Zee Entertainment Enterprises (down 2 per cent), Navneet Education (down 1.69 per cent), TV18 Broadcast (down 1.26 per cent) and Sun TV Network (down 1.19 per cent) too were trading lower. 

The Nifty Media index was trading 1.39 per cent down at 2425.35 around 02:03 pm. 

Benchmark NSE Nifty50 index was up 23.35 points at 11,736.55 while the BSE Sensex was up 126.30 points at 39,182.95.

Among the 50 stocks in the Nifty index, 24 were trading in the green, while 25 were in the red. 

Shares of Tata Motors, Vodafone Idea, SAIL, Bank of Baroda, DLF, YES Bank, SBI, Indiabulls Housing Finance, Ashok Leyland, Bharti Airtel, Tata Steel, ICICI Bank, BHEL, HPCL and Zee Ent. were among the most traded shares on the NSE.

NEW DELHI: FMCG shares were up in Wednesday's morning session with their sectoral index trading higher.

Shares of Marico (up 2.16 per cent) , Godrej Consumer Products (up 2.09 per cent) , Dabur India (up 1.47 per cent) and Colgate-Palmolive (India) (up 1.09 per cent) were trading in the green.

Godrej Industries (up 0.73 per cent) , Jubilant Foodworks (up 0.50 per cent) , United Spirits (up 0.49 per cent) and Emami (up 0.46 per cent) too were trading with gains.

Among the 50 stocks in the Nifty index, 28 were trading in the green, while 22 were in the red. 

Shares of Tata Motors, SAIL, DLF, Bank of Baroda, YES Bank, SBI, Ashok Leyland, Bharti Airtel, Tata Steel, HPCL, Zee Entertainment, Tata Motors and ICICI Bank were among the most traded shares on the NSE.

NEW DELHI: Nifty futures on the Singapore Exchange were trading 5 points, or 0.04 per cent, higher at 11,792, indicating a positive start for the Nifty50. Here are a few stocks which may buzz the most in today’s trade:


Tata Steel: S&P Global Ratings has revised Tata Steel’s outlook to positive on expectations of stable steel prices, reduced chances of acquiring bankrupt Bhushan Power & Steel and the divestment of its low margin European business.


Zee Entertainment: Sony Corporation’s bid to buy Subhash Chandra-controlled ZeeEntertainment Enterprises has been derailed on differences over valuation, pushing a rival consortium of US cable major Comcast to the forefront, four sources told ET.


GVK Power: GVK filed an injunction in the Delhi High Court to block Bidvest from selling its stake in Mumbai International Airport to a third party to preempt a possible takeover threat by the Adani Group. 


Cadila Healthcare: Drug firm Zydus Cadila on Tuesday said it has received a tentative nod from the US health regulator to market its Mirabegron extended-release tablets. The company has received tentative approval from the USFDA to market generic Mirabegron extended-release tablets in the strengths of 25 mg and 50 mg, Zydus Cadila said in a statement. The product is used for the treatment of overactive bladder.


Lupin: Drug major Lupin announced receipt of the Establishment Inspection Report (EIR) from the US health regulator for its Pithampur unit in Madhya Pradesh. US Food and Drug Administration (USFDA) gives EIR on closure of inspection of an establishment that’s the subject of a USFDA inspection.


Mahindra Lifespace: Mahindra group's realty firm Mahindra Lifespace Developers said Tuesday its chief financial officer (CFO) Jayant Manmadkar has resigned from the company.


Jet Airways: A mint-fresh revival plan for financially battered Jet Airways drawn by its lenders has likely come undone after India’s apex court declared rules governing the plan unconstitutional and ultra vires or done beyond one’s legal power or authority.The domestic operations now comprise just 12-15 planes.


Mindtree: The committee of independent directors of Mindtree has appointed Khaitan and Co as legal counsel and ICICI Securities as financial advisor to help the company board take a decision on the open offer made by Larsen and Toubro (L&T).


Tata Power: Tata Power said it has signed a pact with Indraprastha Gas Limited (IGL) for setting up rooftop solar projects in the country.


Hatsun Agro Products: With an aim of delivering farm fresh cow milk to Indian households and strengthening its product portfolio, dairy maker Hatsun Agro Products announced it has unveiled a new brand Hatsun Cow Milk.


Security and Intelligence Services (SIS): The company, which made several acquisitions in the past two years, is exploring more deals in the coming year to keep its strong pace of growth.


Dr Reddy's Laboratories: The company said it has entered into a confidential settlement agreement with US-based biotechnology firm Celgene for its abbreviated new drug submissions (ANDS) related to a generic version of REVLIMID brand capsules pending before Health Canada. REVLIMID is indicated for treatment for multiple myeloma (cancer).

Nitesh Estates: The company plans to sell three plots in southern India to raise ₹440 crore over the next 3-4 months and use the proceeds to reduce debt, the real estate developer’s managing director said, Sobia Khan reports.


IPO watch
Metropolis Heathcare: The diagnostics company has raised Rs 530 crore on Tuesday by allotting 60.24 lakh shares to 26 anchor investors at 880 per share. The 1,200-crore offer, which will run from April 3 to 5, consists of about 15.3 million shares.


RVNL: The IPO by Rail Vikas Nigam (RVNL) was subscribed 48 per cent on the third day of the bidding process on Tuesday. The IPO was subscribed 9 per cent on Day 1 and 18 times on Day 2 of the bidding process on Friday and Monday, respectively. The issue will close today. 


Board meetings 
 The 1,200-crore Metropolis  offer, which will run from April 3 to 5, consists of about 15.3 million shares. 

Analyst calls
• Edelweiss has maintained its hold rating on Coal India with a target price of Rs 243 as e-auction premium will dip given the inventory buildup in the upcoming summer months. Coal India’s shipments in FY19 surpassed the 600MT mark for the first time ever; the 4.7% YoY increase was broadly in line with our expectation, says brokerage. 

• Motilal Oswal has initiated coverage on Godrej Agrovet with a buy rating and set a target price of ₹610 as the company is riding on the back of crop protection and the palm oil business. The diverse nature of of the company’s various businesses de-risks its operations, enabling it to focus on growth, optimise capital efficiency and to maintain its competitive advantage, said the brokerage. 

 • IIFL has maintained its reduce rating on United Spirits with a target price of ₹540 citing moderate sales growth in January-march 2014 quarter. Our industry checks suggest that United Spirits would witness 5% sales growth in 4Q, as the key markets of Maharashtra, Karnataka and UP face demand headwinds, said the brokerage. 

 • ICICI Securities has maintained its buy rating on Kaveri with a target price of ₹598. We note Kaveri has created strong value over the past decade and we remain positive on the medium-term growth outlook, said the brokerage. It expects the company to report revenue and PAT CAGRs of 7.6% and 9.4%, respectively over FY18-FY21. 

 • Emkay has maintained its buy rating on Kajaria Ceramics with a target price of ₹628. We expect 12% volume CAGR in FY18-21E and expect OPM to improve to 16.7%/17.2% in FY20/21E vs. 15.4% in FY19E, said the brokerage. Gas prices have come down by 12% in Q4FY19, which should help in margin expansion, it added. 

 • Kotak Securities has initiated coverage on Welspun Corp with a buy rating and set a target price of ₹161, valuing stock at 4.5 times FY21 estimated EV/EBITDA. Given its strong manufacturing and execution capabilities, strong order backlog coupled with robust bids in the pipeline, we believe, Welspun is better placed compared to its peers, to take advantage of renewed pipe demand globally and in the domestic market, said the brokerage.
